tgt_text: back in new york, i am the head of development for a non-profit called robin hood.
src_text: back in new york, i am the head of development for a non-profit called robin hood.

tgt_text: when i'm not fighting poverty, i'm fighting fires as the assistant captain of a volunteer fire company.
src_text: when i'm not fighting poverty, i'm fighting fires as the assistant captain of a volunteer fire company.

tgt_text: now in our town, where the volunteers supplement a highly skilled career staff, you have to get to the fire scene pretty early to get in on any action.
src_text: now in our town, where the volunteers supplement a highly skilled career staff, you have to get to the fire scene pretty early to get in on any action.

tgt_text: i remember my first fire.
src_text: i remember my first fire.

tgt_text: i was the second volunteer on the scene, so there was a pretty good chance i was going to get in.
src_text: i was the second volunteer on the scene, so there was a pretty good chance i was going to get in.

tgt_text: but still it was a real footrace against the other volunteers to get to the captain in charge to find out what our assignments would be.
src_text: but still it was a real footrace against the other volunteers to get to the captain in charge to find out what our assignments would be.

tgt_text: when i found the captain, he was having a very engaging conversation with the homeowner, who was surely having one of the worst days of her life.
src_text: when i found the captain, he was having a very engaging conversation with the homeowner, who was surely having one of the worst days of her life.

tgt_text: here it was, the middle of the night, she was standing outside in the pouring rain, under an umbrella, in her pajamas, barefoot, while her house was in flames.
src_text: here it was, the middle of the night, she was standing outside in the pouring rain, under an umbrella, in her pajamas, barefoot, while her house was in flames.

tgt_text: the other volunteer who had arrived just before me — let's call him lex luther — (laughter) got to the captain first and was asked to go inside and save the homeowner's dog. the dog! i was stunned with jealousy.
src_text: the other volunteer who had arrived just before me — let's call him lex luther — (laughter) got to the captain first and was asked to go inside and save the homeowner's dog. the dog! i was stunned with jealousy.

tgt_text: here was some lawyer or money manager who, for the rest of his life, gets to tell people that he went into a burning building to save a living creature, just because he beat me by five seconds.
src_text: here was some lawyer or money manager who, for the rest of his life, gets to tell people that he went into a burning building to save a living creature, just because he beat me by five seconds.

tgt_text: well, i was next.
src_text: well, i was next.

tgt_text: the captain waved me over.
src_text: the captain waved me over.

tgt_text: he said, "bezos, i need you to go into the house.
src_text: he said, "bezos, i need you to go into the house.

tgt_text: i need you to go upstairs, past the fire, and i need you to get this woman a pair of shoes. "(laughter) i swear.
src_text: i need you to go upstairs, past the fire, and i need you to get this woman a pair of shoes. "(laughter) i swear.

tgt_text: so, not exactly what i was hoping for, but off i went — up the stairs, down the hall, past the 'real' firefighters, who were pretty much done putting out the fire at this point, into the master bedroom to get a pair of shoes.
src_text: so, not exactly what i was hoping for, but off i went — up the stairs, down the hall, past the 'real' firefighters, who were pretty much done putting out the fire at this point, into the master bedroom to get a pair of shoes.

tgt_text: now i know what you're thinking, but i'm no hero. (laughter) i carried my payload back downstairs where i met my nemesis and the precious dog by the front door.
src_text: now i know what you're thinking, but i'm no hero. (laughter) i carried my payload back downstairs where i met my nemesis and the precious dog by the front door.

tgt_text: we took our treasures outside to the homeowner, where, not surprisingly, his received much more attention than did mine.
src_text: we took our treasures outside to the homeowner, where, not surprisingly, his received much more attention than did mine.

tgt_text: a few weeks later, the department received a letter from the homeowner thanking us for the valiant effort displayed in saving her home.
src_text: a few weeks later, the department received a letter from the homeowner thanking us for the valiant effort displayed in saving her home.

tgt_text: the act of kindness she noted above all others: someone had even gotten her a pair of shoes.
src_text: the act of kindness she noted above all others: someone had even gotten her a pair of shoes.

tgt_text: in both my vocation at robin hood and my avocation as a volunteer firefighter, i am witness to acts of generosity and kindness on a monumental scale, but i'm also witness to acts of grace and courage on an individual basis.
src_text: in both my vocation at robin hood and my avocation as a volunteer firefighter, i am witness to acts of generosity and kindness on a monumental scale, but i'm also witness to acts of grace and courage on an individual basis.

tgt_text: and you know what i've learned? they all matter. so as i look around this room at people who either have achieved, or are on their way to achieving, remarkable levels of success, i would offer this reminder: don't wait.
src_text: and you know what i've learned? they all matter. so as i look around this room at people who either have achieved, or are on their way to achieving, remarkable levels of success, i would offer this reminder: don't wait.

tgt_text: don't wait until you make your first million to make a difference in somebody's life.
src_text: don't wait until you make your first million to make a difference in somebody's life.

tgt_text: if you have something to give, give it now.
src_text: if you have something to give, give it now.

tgt_text: serve food at a soup kitchen. clean up a neighborhood park. be a mentor.
src_text: serve food at a soup kitchen. clean up a neighborhood park. be a mentor.

tgt_text: not every day is going to offer us a chance to save somebody's life, but every day offers us an opportunity to affect one.
src_text: not every day is going to offer us a chance to save somebody's life, but every day offers us an opportunity to affect one.

tgt_text: so get in the game. save the shoes.
src_text: so get in the game. save the shoes.

tgt_text: thank you.
src_text: thank you.

tgt_text: bruno giussani: mark, mark, come back.
src_text: bruno giussani: mark, mark, come back.

tgt_text: i just came back from a community that holds the secret to human survival.
src_text: i just came back from a community that holds the secret to human survival.

tgt_text: it's a place where women run the show, have sex to say hello, and play rules the day — where fun is serious business.
src_text: it's a place where women run the show, have sex to say hello, and play rules the day — where fun is serious business.

tgt_text: and no, this isn't burning man or san francisco. (laughter) ladies and gentlemen, meet your cousins.
src_text: and no, this isn't burning man or san francisco. (laughter) ladies and gentlemen, meet your cousins.

tgt_text: this is the world of wild bonobos in the jungles of congo.
src_text: this is the world of wild bonobos in the jungles of congo.

tgt_text: bonobos are, together with chimpanzees, your living closest relative.
src_text: bonobos are, together with chimpanzees, your living closest relative.

tgt_text: that means we all share a common ancestor, an evolutionary grandmother, who lived around six million years ago.
src_text: that means we all share a common ancestor, an evolutionary grandmother, who lived around six million years ago.

tgt_text: now, chimpanzees are well-known for their aggression.
src_text: now, chimpanzees are well-known for their aggression.

tgt_text: but unfortunately, we have made too much of an emphasis of this aspect in our narratives of human evolution.
src_text: but unfortunately, we have made too much of an emphasis of this aspect in our narratives of human evolution.

tgt_text: but bonobos show us the other side of the coin. while chimpanzees are dominated by big, scary guys, bonobo society is run by empowered females.
src_text: but bonobos show us the other side of the coin. while chimpanzees are dominated by big, scary guys, bonobo society is run by empowered females.

tgt_text: these guys have really worked something out, since this leads to a highly tolerant society where fatal violence has not been observed yet.
src_text: these guys have really worked something out, since this leads to a highly tolerant society where fatal violence has not been observed yet.

tgt_text: but unfortunately, bonobos are the least understood of the great apes.
src_text: but unfortunately, bonobos are the least understood of the great apes.

tgt_text: they live in the depths of the congolese jungle, and it has been very difficult to study them.
src_text: they live in the depths of the congolese jungle, and it has been very difficult to study them.

tgt_text: the congo is a paradox — a land of extraordinary biodiversity and beauty, but also the heart of darkness itself — the scene of a violent conflict that has raged for decades and claimed nearly as many lives as the first world war.
src_text: the congo is a paradox — a land of extraordinary biodiversity and beauty, but also the heart of darkness itself — the scene of a violent conflict that has raged for decades and claimed nearly as many lives as the first world war.

tgt_text: not surprisingly, this destruction also endangers bonobo survival.
src_text: not surprisingly, this destruction also endangers bonobo survival.

tgt_text: bushmeat trades and forest loss means we couldn't fill a small stadium with all the bonobos that are left in the world — and we're not even sure of that to be honest.
src_text: bushmeat trades and forest loss means we couldn't fill a small stadium with all the bonobos that are left in the world — and we're not even sure of that to be honest.

tgt_text: yet, in this land of violence and chaos, you can hear hidden laughter swaying the trees.
src_text: yet, in this land of violence and chaos, you can hear hidden laughter swaying the trees.

tgt_text: who are these cousins? we know them as the "make love, not war" apes since they have frequent, promiscuous and bisexual sex to manage conflict and solve social issues.
src_text: who are these cousins? we know them as the "make love, not war" apes since they have frequent, promiscuous and bisexual sex to manage conflict and solve social issues.

tgt_text: now, i'm not saying this is the solution to all of humanity's problems — since there's more to bonobo life than the kama sutra.
src_text: now, i'm not saying this is the solution to all of humanity's problems — since there's more to bonobo life than the kama sutra.

tgt_text: bonobos, like humans, love to play throughout their entire lives.
src_text: bonobos, like humans, love to play throughout their entire lives.

tgt_text: play is not just child's games.
src_text: play is not just child's games.

tgt_text: for us and them, play is foundational for bonding relationships and fostering tolerance.
src_text: for us and them, play is foundational for bonding relationships and fostering tolerance.

tgt_text: it's where we learn to trust and where we learn about the rules of the game.
src_text: it's where we learn to trust and where we learn about the rules of the game.

tgt_text: play increases creativity and resilience, and it's all about the generation of diversity — diversity of interactions, diversity of behaviors, diversity of connections.
src_text: play increases creativity and resilience, and it's all about the generation of diversity — diversity of interactions, diversity of behaviors, diversity of connections.

tgt_text: and when you watch bonobo play, you're seeing the very evolutionary roots of human laughter, dance and ritual.
src_text: and when you watch bonobo play, you're seeing the very evolutionary roots of human laughter, dance and ritual.

tgt_text: play is the glue that binds us together.
src_text: play is the glue that binds us together.

tgt_text: now, i don't know how you play, but i want to show you a couple of unique clips fresh from the wild.
src_text: now, i don't know how you play, but i want to show you a couple of unique clips fresh from the wild.

tgt_text: first, it's a ball game bonobo-style — and i do not mean football.
src_text: first, it's a ball game bonobo-style — and i do not mean football.

tgt_text: so here, we have a young female and a male engaged in a chase game.
src_text: so here, we have a young female and a male engaged in a chase game.

tgt_text: have a look what she's doing.
src_text: have a look what she's doing.

tgt_text: it might be the evolutionary origin of the phrase, "she's got him by the balls." (laughter) only i think that he's rather loving it here, right?
src_text: it might be the evolutionary origin of the phrase, "she's got him by the balls." (laughter) only i think that he's rather loving it here, right?

tgt_text: yeah. (laughter) so sex play is common in both bonobos and humans.
src_text: yeah. (laughter) so sex play is common in both bonobos and humans.

tgt_text: and this video is really interesting because it shows — this video's really interesting because it shows the inventiveness of bringing unusual elements into play — such as testicles — and also how play both requires trust and fosters trust — while at the same time being tremendous fun.
src_text: and this video is really interesting because it shows — this video's really interesting because it shows the inventiveness of bringing unusual elements into play — such as testicles — and also how play both requires trust and fosters trust — while at the same time being tremendous fun.

tgt_text: but play's a shapeshifter. (laughter) play's a shapeshifter, and it can take many forms, some of which are more quiet, imaginative, curious — maybe where wonder is discovered anew.
src_text: but play's a shapeshifter. (laughter) play's a shapeshifter, and it can take many forms, some of which are more quiet, imaginative, curious — maybe where wonder is discovered anew.

tgt_text: and i want you to see, this is fuku, a young female, and she is quietly playing with water.
src_text: and i want you to see, this is fuku, a young female, and she is quietly playing with water.

tgt_text: i think, like her, we sometimes play alone, and we explore the boundaries of our inner and our outer worlds.
src_text: i think, like her, we sometimes play alone, and we explore the boundaries of our inner and our outer worlds.

tgt_text: and it's that playful curiosity that drives us to explore, drives us to interact, and then the unexpected connections we form are the real hotbed for creativity.
src_text: and it's that playful curiosity that drives us to explore, drives us to interact, and then the unexpected connections we form are the real hotbed for creativity.

tgt_text: so these are just small tasters into the insights that bonobo give us to our past and present.
src_text: so these are just small tasters into the insights that bonobo give us to our past and present.

tgt_text: but they also hold a secret for our future, a future where we need to adapt to an increasingly challenging world through greater creativity and greater cooperation.
src_text: but they also hold a secret for our future, a future where we need to adapt to an increasingly challenging world through greater creativity and greater cooperation.

tgt_text: the secret is that play is the key to these capacities.
src_text: the secret is that play is the key to these capacities.

tgt_text: in other words, play is our adaptive wildcard.
src_text: in other words, play is our adaptive wildcard.

tgt_text: in order to adapt successfully to a changing world, we need to play.
src_text: in order to adapt successfully to a changing world, we need to play.

tgt_text: but will we make the most of our playfulness?
src_text: but will we make the most of our playfulness?

tgt_text: play is not frivolous. play's essential. for bonobos and humans alike, life is not just red in tooth and claw.
src_text: play is not frivolous. play's essential. for bonobos and humans alike, life is not just red in tooth and claw.

tgt_text: in times when it seems least appropriate to play, it might be the times when it is most urgent.
src_text: in times when it seems least appropriate to play, it might be the times when it is most urgent.

tgt_text: and so, my fellow primates, let us embrace this gift from evolution and play together, as we rediscover creativity, fellowship and wonder.
src_text: and so, my fellow primates, let us embrace this gift from evolution and play together, as we rediscover creativity, fellowship and wonder.

tgt_text: thank you.
src_text: thank you.

tgt_text: i want you now to imagine a wearable robot that gives you superhuman abilities, or another one that takes wheelchair users up standing and walking again.
src_text: i want you now to imagine a wearable robot that gives you superhuman abilities, or another one that takes wheelchair users up standing and walking again.

tgt_text: we at berkeley bionics call these robots exoskeletons.
src_text: we at berkeley bionics call these robots exoskeletons.

tgt_text: these are nothing else than something that you put on in the morning, and it will give you extra strength, and it will further enhance your speed, and it will help you, for instance, to manage your balance.
src_text: these are nothing else than something that you put on in the morning, and it will give you extra strength, and it will further enhance your speed, and it will help you, for instance, to manage your balance.

tgt_text: it is actually the true integration of the man and the machine.
src_text: it is actually the true integration of the man and the machine.

tgt_text: but not only that — it will integrate and network you to the universe and other devices out there.
src_text: but not only that — it will integrate and network you to the universe and other devices out there.

tgt_text: this is just not some blue sky thinking.
src_text: this is just not some blue sky thinking.

tgt_text: to show you now what we are working on by starting out talking about the american soldier, that on average does carry about 100 lbs. on their backs, and they are being asked to carry more equipment.
src_text: to show you now what we are working on by starting out talking about the american soldier, that on average does carry about 100 lbs. on their backs, and they are being asked to carry more equipment.

tgt_text: obviously, this is resulting in some major complications — back injuries, 30 percent of them — chronic back injuries.
src_text: obviously, this is resulting in some major complications — back injuries, 30 percent of them — chronic back injuries.

tgt_text: so we thought we would look at this challenge and create an exoskeleton that would help deal with this issue.
src_text: so we thought we would look at this challenge and create an exoskeleton that would help deal with this issue.

tgt_text: so let me now introduce to you hulc — or the human universal load carrier.
src_text: so let me now introduce to you hulc — or the human universal load carrier.

tgt_text: soldier: with the hulc exoskeleton, i can carry 200 lbs. over varied terrain for many hours.
src_text: soldier: with the hulc exoskeleton, i can carry 200 lbs. over varied terrain for many hours.

tgt_text: its flexible design allows for deep squats, crawls and high-agility movements.
src_text: its flexible design allows for deep squats, crawls and high-agility movements.

tgt_text: it senses what i want to do, where i want to go, and then augments my strength and endurance.
src_text: it senses what i want to do, where i want to go, and then augments my strength and endurance.

tgt_text: eythor bender: we are ready with our industry partner to introduce this device, this new exoskeleton this year.
src_text: eythor bender: we are ready with our industry partner to introduce this device, this new exoskeleton this year.

tgt_text: so this is for real.
src_text: so this is for real.

tgt_text: now let's turn our heads towards the wheelchair users, something that i'm particularly passionate about.
src_text: now let's turn our heads towards the wheelchair users, something that i'm particularly passionate about.

tgt_text: there are 68 million people estimated to be in wheelchairs worldwide.
src_text: there are 68 million people estimated to be in wheelchairs worldwide.

tgt_text: this is about one percent of the total population.
src_text: this is about one percent of the total population.

tgt_text: and that's actually a conservative estimate.
src_text: and that's actually a conservative estimate.

tgt_text: we are talking here about, oftentimes, very young individuals with spinal cord injuries, that in the prime of their life — 20s, 30s, 40s — hit a wall and the wheelchair's the only option.
src_text: we are talking here about, oftentimes, very young individuals with spinal cord injuries, that in the prime of their life — 20s, 30s, 40s — hit a wall and the wheelchair's the only option.

tgt_text: but it is also the aging population that is multiplying in numbers.
src_text: but it is also the aging population that is multiplying in numbers.

tgt_text: and the only option, pretty much — when it's stroke or other complications — is the wheelchair.
src_text: and the only option, pretty much — when it's stroke or other complications — is the wheelchair.

tgt_text: and that is actually for the last 500 years, since its very successful introduction, i must say.
src_text: and that is actually for the last 500 years, since its very successful introduction, i must say.

tgt_text: so we thought we would start writing a brand new chapter of mobility.
src_text: so we thought we would start writing a brand new chapter of mobility.

tgt_text: let me now introduce you to elegs that is worn by amanda boxtel that 19 years ago was spinal cord injured, and as a result of that she has not been able to walk for 19 years until now.
src_text: let me now introduce you to elegs that is worn by amanda boxtel that 19 years ago was spinal cord injured, and as a result of that she has not been able to walk for 19 years until now.

tgt_text: amanda boxtel: thank you.
src_text: amanda boxtel: thank you.

tgt_text: eb: amanda is wearing our elegs set. it has sensors. it's completely non-invasive, sensors in the crutches that send signals back to our onboard computer that is sitting here at her back.
src_text: eb: amanda is wearing our elegs set. it has sensors. it's completely non-invasive, sensors in the crutches that send signals back to our onboard computer that is sitting here at her back.

tgt_text: there are battery packs here as well that power motors that are sitting at her hips, as well as her knee joints, that move her forward in this kind of smooth and very natural gait.
src_text: there are battery packs here as well that power motors that are sitting at her hips, as well as her knee joints, that move her forward in this kind of smooth and very natural gait.

tgt_text: ab: i was 24 years old and at the top of my game when a freak summersault while downhill skiing paralyzed me.
src_text: ab: i was 24 years old and at the top of my game when a freak summersault while downhill skiing paralyzed me.

tgt_text: in a split second, i lost all sensation and movement below my pelvis.
src_text: in a split second, i lost all sensation and movement below my pelvis.

tgt_text: not long afterwards, a doctor strode into my hospital room, and he said, "amanda, you'll never walk again." and that was 19 yeas ago.
src_text: not long afterwards, a doctor strode into my hospital room, and he said, "amanda, you'll never walk again." and that was 19 yeas ago.

tgt_text: he robbed every ounce of hope from my being.
src_text: he robbed every ounce of hope from my being.

tgt_text: adaptive technology has since enabled me to learn how to downhill ski again, to rock climb and even handcycle.
src_text: adaptive technology has since enabled me to learn how to downhill ski again, to rock climb and even handcycle.

tgt_text: but nothing has been invented that enables me to walk, until now.
src_text: but nothing has been invented that enables me to walk, until now.

tgt_text: thank you.
src_text: thank you.

tgt_text: eb: as you can see, we have the technology, we have the platforms to sit down and have discussions with you.
src_text: eb: as you can see, we have the technology, we have the platforms to sit down and have discussions with you.

tgt_text: it's in our hands, and we have all the potential here to change the lives of future generations — not only for the soldiers, or for amanda here and all the wheelchair users, but for everyone.
src_text: it's in our hands, and we have all the potential here to change the lives of future generations — not only for the soldiers, or for amanda here and all the wheelchair users, but for everyone.

tgt_text: ab: thanks.
src_text: ab: thanks.

tgt_text: i have spent the past few years putting myself into situations that are usually very difficult and at the same time somewhat dangerous.
src_text: i have spent the past few years putting myself into situations that are usually very difficult and at the same time somewhat dangerous.

tgt_text: i went to prison — difficult.
src_text: i went to prison — difficult.

tgt_text: i worked in a coal mine — dangerous.
src_text: i worked in a coal mine — dangerous.

tgt_text: i filmed in war zones — difficult and dangerous.
src_text: i filmed in war zones — difficult and dangerous.

tgt_text: and i spent 30 days eating nothing but this — fun in the beginning, little difficult in the middle, very dangerous in the end.
src_text: and i spent 30 days eating nothing but this — fun in the beginning, little difficult in the middle, very dangerous in the end.

tgt_text: in fact, most of my career, i've been immersing myself into seemingly horrible situations for the whole goal of trying to examine societal issues in a way that make them engaging, that make them interesting, that hopefully break them down in a way that make them entertaining and accessible to an audience.
src_text: in fact, most of my career, i've been immersing myself into seemingly horrible situations for the whole goal of trying to examine societal issues in a way that make them engaging, that make them interesting, that hopefully break them down in a way that make them entertaining and accessible to an audience.

tgt_text: so when i knew i was coming here to do a ted talk that was going to look at the world of branding and sponsorship, i knew i would want to do something a little different.
src_text: so when i knew i was coming here to do a ted talk that was going to look at the world of branding and sponsorship, i knew i would want to do something a little different.

tgt_text: so as some of you may or may not have heard, a couple weeks ago, i took out an ad on ebay.
src_text: so as some of you may or may not have heard, a couple weeks ago, i took out an ad on ebay.

tgt_text: i sent out some facebook messages, some twitter messages, and i gave people the opportunity to buy the naming rights to my 2011 ted talk. (laughter) that's right, some lucky individual, corporation, for-profit or non-profit, was going to get the once-in-a-lifetime opportunity — because i'm sure chris anderson will never let it happen again — (laughter) to buy the naming rights to the talk you're watching right now, that at the time didn't have a title, didn't really have a lot of content and didn't really give much hint as to what the subject matter would actually be.
src_text: i sent out some facebook messages, some twitter messages, and i gave people the opportunity to buy the naming rights to my 2011 ted talk. (laughter) that's right, some lucky individual, corporation, for-profit or non-profit, was going to get the once-in-a-lifetime opportunity — because i'm sure chris anderson will never let it happen again — (laughter) to buy the naming rights to the talk you're watching right now, that at the time didn't have a title, didn't really have a lot of content and didn't really give much hint as to what the subject matter would actually be.

tgt_text: so what you were getting was this: your name here presents: my ted talk that you have no idea what the subject is and, depending on the content, could ultimately blow up in your face, especially if i make you or your company look stupid for doing it.
src_text: so what you were getting was this: your name here presents: my ted talk that you have no idea what the subject is and, depending on the content, could ultimately blow up in your face, especially if i make you or your company look stupid for doing it.

tgt_text: but that being said, it's a very good media opportunity. (laughter) you know how many people watch these ted talks? it's a lot. that's just a working title, by the way. (laughter) so even with that caveat, i knew that someone would buy the naming rights.
src_text: but that being said, it's a very good media opportunity. (laughter) you know how many people watch these ted talks? it's a lot. that's just a working title, by the way. (laughter) so even with that caveat, i knew that someone would buy the naming rights.

tgt_text: now if you'd have asked me that a year ago, i wouldn't have been able to tell you that with any certainty.
src_text: now if you'd have asked me that a year ago, i wouldn't have been able to tell you that with any certainty.

tgt_text: but in the new project that i'm working on, my new film, we examine the world of marketing, advertising.
src_text: but in the new project that i'm working on, my new film, we examine the world of marketing, advertising.

tgt_text: and as i said earlier, i put myself in some pretty horrible situations over the years, but nothing could prepare me, nothing could ready me, for anything as difficult or as dangerous as going into the rooms with these guys. (laughter) you see, i had this idea for a movie.
src_text: and as i said earlier, i put myself in some pretty horrible situations over the years, but nothing could prepare me, nothing could ready me, for anything as difficult or as dangerous as going into the rooms with these guys. (laughter) you see, i had this idea for a movie.

tgt_text: (video) morgan spurlock: what i want to do is make a film all about product placement, marketing and advertising, where the entire film is funded by product placement, marketing and advertising.
src_text: (video) morgan spurlock: what i want to do is make a film all about product placement, marketing and advertising, where the entire film is funded by product placement, marketing and advertising.

tgt_text: so the movie will be called "the greatest movie ever sold." so what happens in "the greatest movie ever sold," is that everything from top to bottom, from start to finish, is branded from beginning to end — from the above-the-title sponsor that you'll see in the movie, which is brand x. now this brand, the qualcomm stadium, the staples center... these people will be married to the film in perpetuity — forever.

tgt_text: but we did get 17 brand partners who were willing to relinquish that control, who wanted to be in business with someone as mindful and as playful as myself and who ultimately empowered us to tell stories that normally we wouldn't be able to tell — stories that an advertiser would normally never get behind.

tgt_text: what i always believe is that if you take chances, if you take risks, that in those risks will come opportunity.

tgt_text: i believe that when you push people away from that, you're pushing them more towards failure.

tgt_text: i believe that when you train your employees to be risk averse, then you're preparing your whole company to be reward challenged.

tgt_text: tempt was one of the foremost graffiti artists in the 80s.

tgt_text: and he came up home from a run one day and said, "dad, my legs are tingling." and that was the onset of als.

tgt_text: i was exposed to him. i have a company that does design and animation, so obviously graffiti is definitely an intricate part of what we admire and respect in the art world.

tgt_text: and so we decided that we were going to sponsor tony, tempt, and his cause.

tgt_text: so i went and met with his brother and father and said, "we're going to give you this money. what are you going to do with it?" and his brother said, "i just want to be able to talk to tony again.

tgt_text: i met these guys called grl, graffiti research lab, and they have a technology that allows them to project a light onto any surface and then, with a laser pointer, draw on it, and it just registers the negative space.
src_text: i met these guys called grl, graffiti research lab, and they have a technology that allows them to project a light onto any surface and then, with a laser pointer, draw on it, and it just registers the negative space.

tgt_text: so they go around and do art installations like this.

tgt_text: so i went home and was having dinner with my wife and was telling her about this, and we were like, "well wait a second. if we know that this technology exists where you can use your eyes to control things, why don't we figure out a way for tempt to control a laser and he could do graf again? well that would be awesome."

tgt_text: we took a ps3 camera, hacked it open, mounted it to an led light, and now there's a device that is free — you build this yourself, we publish the code for free, you download the software for free.

tgt_text: and this is the question i want everyone to ask yourself every single day when you come up with something you feel that needs to be done: if not now, then when?

src_text: how would you like to be better than you are?

tgt_text: suppose i said that, with just a few changes in your genes, you could get a better memory — more precise, more accurate and quicker.

tgt_text: evolution has been a perennial topic here at the ted conference, but i want to give you today one doctor's take on the subject.
src_text: evolution has been a perennial topic here at the ted conference, but i want to give you today one doctor's take on the subject.

tgt_text: the great 20th-century geneticist, t.g. dobzhansky, who was also a communicant in the russian orthodox church, once wrote an essay that he titled "nothing in biology makes sense except in the light of evolution." now if you are one of those who does not accept the evidence for biological evolution, this would be a very good time to turn off your hearing aid, take out your personal communications device — i give you permission — and perhaps take another look at kathryn schultz's book on being wrong, because nothing in the rest of this talk is going to make any sense whatsoever to you. (laughter) but if you do accept biological evolution, consider this: is it just about the past, or is it about the future?
src_text: the great 20th-century geneticist, t.g. dobzhansky, who was also a communicant in the russian orthodox church, once wrote an essay that he titled "nothing in biology makes sense except in the light of evolution." now if you are one of those who does not accept the evidence for biological evolution, this would be a very good time to turn off your hearing aid, take out your personal communications device — i give you permission — and perhaps take another look at kathryn schultz's book on being wrong, because nothing in the rest of this talk is going to make any sense whatsoever to you. (laughter) but if you do accept biological evolution, consider this: is it just about the past, or is it about the future?

tgt_text: does it apply to others, or does it apply to us?
src_text: does it apply to others, or does it apply to us?

tgt_text: this is another look at the tree of life.
src_text: this is another look at the tree of life.

tgt_text: in this picture, i've put a bush with a center branching out in all directions, because if you look at the edges of the tree of life, every existing species at the tips of those branches has succeeded in evolutionary terms: it has survived; it has demonstrated a fitness to its environment.
src_text: in this picture, i've put a bush with a center branching out in all directions, because if you look at the edges of the tree of life, every existing species at the tips of those branches has succeeded in evolutionary terms: it has survived; it has demonstrated a fitness to its environment.

tgt_text: the human part of this branch, way out on one end, is, of course, the one that we are most interested in.
src_text: the human part of this branch, way out on one end, is, of course, the one that we are most interested in.

tgt_text: we branch off of a common ancestor to modern chimpanzees about six or eight million years ago.
src_text: we branch off of a common ancestor to modern chimpanzees about six or eight million years ago.

tgt_text: in the interval, there have been perhaps 20 or 25 different species of hominids.
src_text: in the interval, there have been perhaps 20 or 25 different species of hominids.

tgt_text: some have come and gone.
src_text: some have come and gone.

tgt_text: we have been here for about 130,000 years.
src_text: we have been here for about 130,000 years.

tgt_text: it may seem like we're quite remote from other parts of this tree of life, but actually, for the most part, the basic machinery of our cells is pretty much the same.
src_text: it may seem like we're quite remote from other parts of this tree of life, but actually, for the most part, the basic machinery of our cells is pretty much the same.

tgt_text: do you realize that we can take advantage and commandeer the machinery of a common bacterium to produce the protein of human insulin used to treat diabetics?
src_text: do you realize that we can take advantage and commandeer the machinery of a common bacterium to produce the protein of human insulin used to treat diabetics?

tgt_text: this is not like human insulin; this is the same protein that is chemically indistinguishable from what comes out of your pancreas.
src_text: this is not like human insulin; this is the same protein that is chemically indistinguishable from what comes out of your pancreas.

tgt_text: and speaking of bacteria, do you realize that each of us carries in our gut more bacteria than there are cells in the rest of our body?
src_text: and speaking of bacteria, do you realize that each of us carries in our gut more bacteria than there are cells in the rest of our body?

tgt_text: maybe 10 times more.
src_text: maybe 10 times more.

tgt_text: i mean think of it, when antonio damasio asks about your self-image, do you think about the bacteria?
src_text: i mean think of it, when antonio damasio asks about your self-image, do you think about the bacteria?

tgt_text: our gut is a wonderfully hospitable environment for those bacteria.
src_text: our gut is a wonderfully hospitable environment for those bacteria.

tgt_text: it's warm, it's dark, it's moist, it's very cozy.
src_text: it's warm, it's dark, it's moist, it's very cozy.

tgt_text: and you're going to provide all the nutrition that they could possibly want with no effort on their part.
src_text: and you're going to provide all the nutrition that they could possibly want with no effort on their part.

tgt_text: it's really like an easy street for bacteria, with the occasional interruption of the unintended forced rush to the exit.
src_text: it's really like an easy street for bacteria, with the occasional interruption of the unintended forced rush to the exit.

tgt_text: but otherwise, you are a wonderful environment for those bacteria, just as they are essential to your life.
src_text: but otherwise, you are a wonderful environment for those bacteria, just as they are essential to your life.

tgt_text: they help in the digestion of essential nutrients, and they protect you against certain diseases.
src_text: they help in the digestion of essential nutrients, and they protect you against certain diseases.

tgt_text: but what will come in the future?
src_text: but what will come in the future?

tgt_text: are we at some kind of evolutionary equipoise as a species?
src_text: are we at some kind of evolutionary equipoise as a species?

tgt_text: or, are we destined to become something different — something, perhaps, even better adapted to the environment?
src_text: or, are we destined to become something different — something, perhaps, even better adapted to the environment?

tgt_text: now let's take a step back in time to the big bang, 14 billion years ago — the earth, the solar system, about four and a half billion years — the first signs of proto-life, maybe three to four billion years ago on earth — the first multi-celled organisms, perhaps as much as 800 or a billion years ago — and then the human species, finally emerging in the last 130,000 years.
src_text: now let's take a step back in time to the big bang, 14 billion years ago — the earth, the solar system, about four and a half billion years — the first signs of proto-life, maybe three to four billion years ago on earth — the first multi-celled organisms, perhaps as much as 800 or a billion years ago — and then the human species, finally emerging in the last 130,000 years.

tgt_text: in this vast unfinished symphony of the universe, life on earth is like a brief measure; the animal kingdom, like a single measure; and human life, a small grace note. that was us. that also constitutes the entertainment portion of this talk, so i hope you enjoyed it.
src_text: in this vast unfinished symphony of the universe, life on earth is like a brief measure; the animal kingdom, like a single measure; and human life, a small grace note. that was us. that also constitutes the entertainment portion of this talk, so i hope you enjoyed it.

tgt_text: (laughter)
src_text: (laughter)

tgt_text: now when i was a freshman in college, i took my first biology class.
src_text: now when i was a freshman in college, i took my first biology class.

tgt_text: i was fascinated by the elegance and beauty of biology.
src_text: i was fascinated by the elegance and beauty of biology.

tgt_text: i became enamored of the power of evolution, and i realized something very fundamental: in most of the existence of life in single-celled organisms, each cell simply divides, and all of the genetic energy of that cell is carried on in both daughter cells.
src_text: i became enamored of the power of evolution, and i realized something very fundamental: in most of the existence of life in single-celled organisms, each cell simply divides, and all of the genetic energy of that cell is carried on in both daughter cells.

tgt_text: but at the time multi-celled organisms come online, things start to change.
src_text: but at the time multi-celled organisms come online, things start to change.

tgt_text: sexual reproduction enters the picture.
src_text: sexual reproduction enters the picture.

tgt_text: and very importantly, with the introduction of sexual reproduction that passes on the genome, the rest of the body becomes expendable.
src_text: and very importantly, with the introduction of sexual reproduction that passes on the genome, the rest of the body becomes expendable.

tgt_text: in fact, you could say that the inevitability of the death of our bodies enters in evolutionary time at the same moment as sexual reproduction.
src_text: in fact, you could say that the inevitability of the death of our bodies enters in evolutionary time at the same moment as sexual reproduction.

tgt_text: now i have to confess, when i was a college undergraduate, i thought, okay, sex / death, sex / death, death for sex — it seemed pretty reasonable at the time, but with each passing year, i've come to have increasing doubts.
src_text: now i have to confess, when i was a college undergraduate, i thought, okay, sex / death, sex / death, death for sex — it seemed pretty reasonable at the time, but with each passing year, i've come to have increasing doubts.

tgt_text: i've come to understand the sentiments of george burns, who was performing still in las vegas well into his 90s.
src_text: i've come to understand the sentiments of george burns, who was performing still in las vegas well into his 90s.

tgt_text: and one night, there's a knock at his hotel room door.
src_text: and one night, there's a knock at his hotel room door.

tgt_text: he answers the door.
src_text: he answers the door.

tgt_text: standing before him is a gorgeous, scantily clad showgirl.
src_text: standing before him is a gorgeous, scantily clad showgirl.

tgt_text: she looks at him and says, "i'm here for super sex." "that's fine," says george, "i'll take the soup."
src_text: she looks at him and says, "i'm here for super sex." "that's fine," says george, "i'll take the soup."

tgt_text: i came to realize, as a physician, that i was working toward a goal which was different from the goal of evolution — not necessarily contradictory, just different.
src_text: i came to realize, as a physician, that i was working toward a goal which was different from the goal of evolution — not necessarily contradictory, just different.

tgt_text: i was trying to preserve the body.
src_text: i was trying to preserve the body.

tgt_text: i wanted to keep us healthy.
src_text: i wanted to keep us healthy.

tgt_text: i wanted to restore health from disease.
src_text: i wanted to restore health from disease.

tgt_text: i wanted us to live long and healthy lives.
src_text: i wanted us to live long and healthy lives.

tgt_text: evolution is all about passing on the genome to the next generation, adapting and surviving through generation after generation.
src_text: evolution is all about passing on the genome to the next generation, adapting and surviving through generation after generation.

tgt_text: from an evolutionary point of view, you and i are like the booster rockets designed to send the genetic payload into the next level of orbit and then drop off into the sea.
src_text: from an evolutionary point of view, you and i are like the booster rockets designed to send the genetic payload into the next level of orbit and then drop off into the sea.

tgt_text: i think we would all understand the sentiment that woody allen expressed when he said, "i don't want to achieve immortality through my work.
src_text: i think we would all understand the sentiment that woody allen expressed when he said, "i don't want to achieve immortality through my work.

tgt_text: i want to achieve it through not dying. "
src_text: i want to achieve it through not dying. "

tgt_text: evolution does not necessarily favor the longest-lived.
src_text: evolution does not necessarily favor the longest-lived.

tgt_text: it doesn't necessarily favor the biggest or the strongest or the fastest, and not even the smartest.
src_text: it doesn't necessarily favor the biggest or the strongest or the fastest, and not even the smartest.

tgt_text: evolution favors those creatures best adapted to their environment.
src_text: evolution favors those creatures best adapted to their environment.

tgt_text: that is the sole test of survival and success. at the bottom of the ocean, bacteria that are thermophilic and can survive at the steam vent heat that would otherwise produce, if fish were there, sous-vide cooked fish, nevertheless, have managed to make that a hospitable environment for them.
src_text: that is the sole test of survival and success. at the bottom of the ocean, bacteria that are thermophilic and can survive at the steam vent heat that would otherwise produce, if fish were there, sous-vide cooked fish, nevertheless, have managed to make that a hospitable environment for them.

tgt_text: so what does this mean, as we look back at what has happened in evolution, and as we think about the place again of humans in evolution, and particularly as we look ahead to the next phase, i would say that there are a number of possibilities.
src_text: so what does this mean, as we look back at what has happened in evolution, and as we think about the place again of humans in evolution, and particularly as we look ahead to the next phase, i would say that there are a number of possibilities.

tgt_text: the first is that we will not evolve.
src_text: the first is that we will not evolve.

tgt_text: we have reached a kind of equipoise.
src_text: we have reached a kind of equipoise.

tgt_text: and the reasoning behind that would be, first, we have, through medicine, managed to preserve a lot of genes that would otherwise be selected out and be removed from the population.
src_text: and the reasoning behind that would be, first, we have, through medicine, managed to preserve a lot of genes that would otherwise be selected out and be removed from the population.

tgt_text: and secondly, we as a species have so configured our environment that we have managed to make it adapt to us as well as we adapt to it. and by the way, we immigrate and circulate and intermix so much that you can't any longer have the isolation that is necessary for evolution to take place.
src_text: and secondly, we as a species have so configured our environment that we have managed to make it adapt to us as well as we adapt to it. and by the way, we immigrate and circulate and intermix so much that you can't any longer have the isolation that is necessary for evolution to take place.

tgt_text: a second possibility is that there will be evolution of the traditional kind, natural, imposed by the forces of nature.
src_text: a second possibility is that there will be evolution of the traditional kind, natural, imposed by the forces of nature.

tgt_text: and the argument here would be that the wheels of evolution grind slowly, but they are inexorable.
src_text: and the argument here would be that the wheels of evolution grind slowly, but they are inexorable.

tgt_text: and as far as isolation goes, when we as a species do colonize distant planets, there will be the isolation and the environmental changes that could produce evolution in the natural way.
src_text: and as far as isolation goes, when we as a species do colonize distant planets, there will be the isolation and the environmental changes that could produce evolution in the natural way.

tgt_text: but there's a third possibility, an enticing, intriguing and frightening possibility. i call it neo-evolution — the new evolution that is not simply natural, but guided and chosen by us as individuals in the choices that we will make.
src_text: but there's a third possibility, an enticing, intriguing and frightening possibility. i call it neo-evolution — the new evolution that is not simply natural, but guided and chosen by us as individuals in the choices that we will make.

tgt_text: now how could this come about?
src_text: now how could this come about?

tgt_text: how could it be possible that we would do this?
src_text: how could it be possible that we would do this?

tgt_text: consider, first, the reality that people today, in some cultures, are making choices about their offspring.
src_text: consider, first, the reality that people today, in some cultures, are making choices about their offspring.

tgt_text: they're, in some cultures, choosing to have more males than females.
src_text: they're, in some cultures, choosing to have more males than females.

tgt_text: it's not necessarily good for the society, but it's what the individual and the family are choosing.
src_text: it's not necessarily good for the society, but it's what the individual and the family are choosing.

tgt_text: think also, if it were possible ever for you to choose, not simply to choose the sex of your child, but for you in your body to make the genetic adjustments that would cure or prevent diseases.
src_text: think also, if it were possible ever for you to choose, not simply to choose the sex of your child, but for you in your body to make the genetic adjustments that would cure or prevent diseases.

tgt_text: what if you could make the genetic changes to eliminate diabetes or alzheimer's or reduce the risk of cancer or eliminate stroke?
src_text: what if you could make the genetic changes to eliminate diabetes or alzheimer's or reduce the risk of cancer or eliminate stroke?

tgt_text: wouldn't you want to make those changes in your genes?
src_text: wouldn't you want to make those changes in your genes?

tgt_text: if we look ahead, these kind of changes are going to be increasingly possible.
src_text: if we look ahead, these kind of changes are going to be increasingly possible.

tgt_text: the human genome project started in 1990, and it took 13 years.
src_text: the human genome project started in 1990, and it took 13 years.

tgt_text: it cost 2.7 billion dollars.
src_text: it cost 2.7 billion dollars.

tgt_text: the year after it was finished in 2004, you could do the same job for 20 million dollars in three to four months.
src_text: the year after it was finished in 2004, you could do the same job for 20 million dollars in three to four months.

tgt_text: today, you can have a complete sequence of the three billion base pairs in the human genome at a cost of about 20,000 dollars and in the space of about a week.
src_text: today, you can have a complete sequence of the three billion base pairs in the human genome at a cost of about 20,000 dollars and in the space of about a week.

tgt_text: it won't be very long before the reality will be the 1,000-dollar human genome, and it will be increasingly available for everyone.
src_text: it won't be very long before the reality will be the 1,000-dollar human genome, and it will be increasingly available for everyone.

tgt_text: just a week ago, the national academy of engineering awarded its draper prize to francis arnold and willem stemmer, two scientists who independently developed techniques to encourage the natural process of evolution to work faster and to lead to desirable proteins in a more efficient way — what frances arnold calls "directed evolution." a couple of years ago, the lasker prize was awarded to the scientist shinya yamanaka for his research in which he took an adult skin cell, a fibroblast, and by manipulating just four genes, he induced that cell to revert to a pluripotential stem cell — a cell potentially capable of becoming any cell in your body.
src_text: just a week ago, the national academy of engineering awarded its draper prize to francis arnold and willem stemmer, two scientists who independently developed techniques to encourage the natural process of evolution to work faster and to lead to desirable proteins in a more efficient way — what frances arnold calls "directed evolution." a couple of years ago, the lasker prize was awarded to the scientist shinya yamanaka for his research in which he took an adult skin cell, a fibroblast, and by manipulating just four genes, he induced that cell to revert to a pluripotential stem cell — a cell potentially capable of becoming any cell in your body.

tgt_text: these changes are coming. the same technology that has produced the human insulin in bacteria can make viruses that will not only protect you against themselves, but induce immunity against other viruses.
src_text: these changes are coming. the same technology that has produced the human insulin in bacteria can make viruses that will not only protect you against themselves, but induce immunity against other viruses.

tgt_text: believe it or not, there's an experimental trial going on with vaccine against influenza that has been grown in the cells of a tobacco plant.
src_text: believe it or not, there's an experimental trial going on with vaccine against influenza that has been grown in the cells of a tobacco plant.

tgt_text: can you imagine something good coming out of tobacco?
src_text: can you imagine something good coming out of tobacco?

tgt_text: these are all reality today, and [in] the future, will be evermore possible.
src_text: these are all reality today, and [in] the future, will be evermore possible.

tgt_text: imagine then just two other little changes.
src_text: imagine then just two other little changes.

tgt_text: you can change the cells in your body, but what if you could change the cells in your offspring?
src_text: you can change the cells in your body, but what if you could change the cells in your offspring?

tgt_text: what if you could change the sperm and the ova, or change the newly fertilized egg, and give your offspring a better chance at a healthier life — eliminate the diabetes, eliminate the hemophilia, reduce the risk of cancer?
src_text: what if you could change the sperm and the ova, or change the newly fertilized egg, and give your offspring a better chance at a healthier life — eliminate the diabetes, eliminate the hemophilia, reduce the risk of cancer?

tgt_text: who doesn't want healthier children?
src_text: who doesn't want healthier children?

tgt_text: and then, that same analytic technology, that same engine of science that can produce the changes to prevent disease, will also enable us to adopt super-attributes, hyper-capacities — that better memory.
src_text: and then, that same analytic technology, that same engine of science that can produce the changes to prevent disease, will also enable us to adopt super-attributes, hyper-capacities — that better memory.

tgt_text: why not have the quick wit of a ken jennings, especially if you can augment it with the next generation of the watson machine?
src_text: why not have the quick wit of a ken jennings, especially if you can augment it with the next generation of the watson machine?

tgt_text: why not have the quick twitch muscle that will enable you to run faster and longer?
src_text: why not have the quick twitch muscle that will enable you to run faster and longer?

tgt_text: why not live longer?
src_text: why not live longer?

tgt_text: these will be irresistible.
src_text: these will be irresistible.

tgt_text: and when we are at a position where we can pass it on to the next generation, and we can adopt the attributes we want, we will have converted old-style evolution into neo-evolution.
src_text: and when we are at a position where we can pass it on to the next generation, and we can adopt the attributes we want, we will have converted old-style evolution into neo-evolution.

tgt_text: we'll take a process that normally might require 100,000 years, and we can compress it down to a thousand years — and maybe even in the next 100 years.
src_text: we'll take a process that normally might require 100,000 years, and we can compress it down to a thousand years — and maybe even in the next 100 years.

tgt_text: these are choices that your grandchildren, or their grandchildren, are going to have before them.
src_text: these are choices that your grandchildren, or their grandchildren, are going to have before them.

tgt_text: will we use these choices to make a society that is better, that is more successful, that is kinder?
src_text: will we use these choices to make a society that is better, that is more successful, that is kinder?

tgt_text: or, will we selectively choose different attributes that we want for some of us and not for others of us?
src_text: or, will we selectively choose different attributes that we want for some of us and not for others of us?

tgt_text: will we make a society that is more boring and more uniform, or more robust and more versatile?
src_text: will we make a society that is more boring and more uniform, or more robust and more versatile?

tgt_text: these are the kinds of questions that we will have to face.
src_text: these are the kinds of questions that we will have to face.

tgt_text: and most profoundly of all, will we ever be able to develop the wisdom, and to inherit the wisdom, that we'll need to make these choices wisely?
src_text: and most profoundly of all, will we ever be able to develop the wisdom, and to inherit the wisdom, that we'll need to make these choices wisely?

tgt_text: for better or worse, and sooner than you may think, these choices will be up to us.
src_text: for better or worse, and sooner than you may think, these choices will be up to us.

tgt_text: thank you.
src_text: thank you.

tgt_text: good afternoon, everybody. i've got something to show you. (laughter) think about this as a pixel, a flying pixel.
src_text: good afternoon, everybody. i've got something to show you. (laughter) think about this as a pixel, a flying pixel.

tgt_text: this is what we call, in our lab, sensible design.
src_text: this is what we call, in our lab, sensible design.

tgt_text: let me tell you a bit about it.
src_text: let me tell you a bit about it.

tgt_text: now if you take this picture — i'm italian originally, and every boy in italy grows up with this picture on the wall of his bedroom — but the reason i'm showing you this is that something very interesting happened in formula 1 racing over the past couple of decades.
src_text: now if you take this picture — i'm italian originally, and every boy in italy grows up with this picture on the wall of his bedroom — but the reason i'm showing you this is that something very interesting happened in formula 1 racing over the past couple of decades.

tgt_text: now some time ago, if you wanted to win a formula 1 race, you take a budget, and you bet your budget on a good driver and a good car.
src_text: now some time ago, if you wanted to win a formula 1 race, you take a budget, and you bet your budget on a good driver and a good car.

tgt_text: and if the car and the driver were good enough, then you'd win the race.
src_text: and if the car and the driver were good enough, then you'd win the race.

tgt_text: now today, if you want to win the race, actually you need also something like this — something that monitors the car in real time, has a few thousand sensors collecting information from the car, transmitting this information into the system, and then processing it and using it in order to go back to the car with decisions and changing things in real time as information is collected.
src_text: now today, if you want to win the race, actually you need also something like this — something that monitors the car in real time, has a few thousand sensors collecting information from the car, transmitting this information into the system, and then processing it and using it in order to go back to the car with decisions and changing things in real time as information is collected.

tgt_text: this is what, in engineering terms, you would call a real time control system.
src_text: this is what, in engineering terms, you would call a real time control system.

tgt_text: and basically, it's a system made of two components — a sensing and an actuating component.
src_text: and basically, it's a system made of two components — a sensing and an actuating component.

tgt_text: what is interesting today is that real time control systems are starting to enter into our lives.
src_text: what is interesting today is that real time control systems are starting to enter into our lives.

tgt_text: our cities, over the past few years, just have been blanketed with networks, electronics.
src_text: our cities, over the past few years, just have been blanketed with networks, electronics.

tgt_text: they're becoming like computers in open air.
src_text: they're becoming like computers in open air.

tgt_text: and, as computers in open air, they're starting to respond in a different way to be able to be sensed and to be actuated.
src_text: and, as computers in open air, they're starting to respond in a different way to be able to be sensed and to be actuated.

tgt_text: if we fix cities, actually it's a big deal.
src_text: if we fix cities, actually it's a big deal.

tgt_text: just as an aside, i wanted to mention, cities are only two percent of the earth's crust, but they are 50 percent of the world's population.
src_text: just as an aside, i wanted to mention, cities are only two percent of the earth's crust, but they are 50 percent of the world's population.

tgt_text: they are 75 percent of the energy consumption — up to 80 percent of co2 emissions.
src_text: they are 75 percent of the energy consumption — up to 80 percent of co2 emissions.

tgt_text: so if we're able to do something with cities, that's a big deal.
src_text: so if we're able to do something with cities, that's a big deal.

tgt_text: beyond cities, all of this sensing and actuating is entering our everyday objects.
src_text: beyond cities, all of this sensing and actuating is entering our everyday objects.

tgt_text: that's from an exhibition that paola antonelli is organizing at moma later this year, during the summer.
src_text: that's from an exhibition that paola antonelli is organizing at moma later this year, during the summer.

tgt_text: it's called "talk to me." well our objects, our environment is starting to talk back to us.
src_text: it's called "talk to me." well our objects, our environment is starting to talk back to us.

tgt_text: in a certain sense, it's almost as if every atom out there were becoming both a sensor and an actuator.
src_text: in a certain sense, it's almost as if every atom out there were becoming both a sensor and an actuator.

tgt_text: and that is radically changing the interaction we have as humans with the environment out there.

tgt_text: in a certain sense, it's almost as if the old dream of michelangelo... you know, when michelangelo sculpted the moses, at the end it said that he took the hammer, threw it at the moses — actually you can still see a small chip underneath — and said, shouted, "perché non parli?

tgt_text: and i think what is remarkable that has happened over the past couple of years is that, over the past couple of decades, we went from the physical world to the digital one.

tgt_text: now today, for the first time — and the obama campaign showed us this — we can go from the digital world, from the self-organizing power of networks, to the physical one.

src_text: but i bet playing with this car stop taught him a really valuable lesson, and that's that large things don't let you get right past them, and that they stay in one place.

tgt_text: and so this is a great conceptual model to have of the world, unless you're a particle physicist.

tgt_text: and when they play with their particles, they find they do all sorts of really weird things — like they can fly right through walls, or they can be in two different places at the same time.

tgt_text: and so they wrote down all these observations, and they called it the theory of quantum mechanics.

tgt_text: because if everything is made up of little particles and all the little particles follow quantum mechanics, then shouldn't everything just follow quantum mechanics?
src_text: because if everything is made up of little particles and all the little particles follow quantum mechanics, then shouldn't everything just follow quantum mechanics?

tgt_text: i don't see any reason why it shouldn't.

src_text: and so i'd feel a lot better about the whole thing if we could somehow show that an everyday object also follows quantum mechanics.

tgt_text: so a few years ago, i set off to do just that.

src_text: so what we're looking at is a little chunk of metal, and it's shaped like a diving board, and it's sticking out over a ledge.

tgt_text: and so i made this thing in nearly the same way as you make a computer chip.

tgt_text: i went into a clean room with a fresh silicon wafer, and then i just cranked away at all the big machines for about 100 hours.

tgt_text: for the last stuff, i had to build my own machine — to make this swimming pool-shaped hole underneath the device.

tgt_text: this device has the ability to be in a quantum superposition, but it needs a little help to do it.

tgt_text: here, let me give you an analogy.

tgt_text: you know how uncomfortable it is to be in a crowded elevator?

tgt_text: i mean, when i'm in an elevator all alone, i do all sorts of weird things, but then other people get on board and i stop doing those things because i don't want to bother them, or, frankly, scare them.
src_text: i mean, when i'm in an elevator all alone, i do all sorts of weird things, but then other people get on board and i stop doing those things because i don't want to bother them, or, frankly, scare them.

tgt_text: so quantum mechanics says that inanimate objects feel the same way.

tgt_text: the fellow passengers for inanimate objects are not just people, but it's also the light shining on it and the wind blowing past it and the heat of the room.
src_text: the fellow passengers for inanimate objects are not just people, but it's also the light shining on it and the wind blowing past it and the heat of the room.

tgt_text: and so we knew, if we wanted to see this piece of metal behave quantum mechanically, we're going to have to kick out all the other passengers.
src_text: and so we knew, if we wanted to see this piece of metal behave quantum mechanically, we're going to have to kick out all the other passengers.

tgt_text: and so that's what we did.
src_text: and so that's what we did.

tgt_text: we turned off the lights, and then we put it in a vacuum and sucked out all the air, and then we cooled it down to just a fraction of a degree above absolute zero.
src_text: we turned off the lights, and then we put it in a vacuum and sucked out all the air, and then we cooled it down to just a fraction of a degree above absolute zero.

tgt_text: now, all alone in the elevator, the little chunk of metal is free to act however it wanted.

tgt_text: and so we measured its motion.
src_text: and so we measured its motion.

tgt_text: we found it was moving in really weird ways.

tgt_text: instead of just sitting perfectly still, it was vibrating, and the way it was vibrating was breathing something like this — like expanding and contracting bellows.
src_text: instead of just sitting perfectly still, it was vibrating, and the way it was vibrating was breathing something like this — like expanding and contracting bellows.

tgt_text: and by giving it a gentle nudge, we were able to make it both vibrate and not vibrate at the same time — something that's only allowed with quantum mechanics.
src_text: and by giving it a gentle nudge, we were able to make it both vibrate and not vibrate at the same time — something that's only allowed with quantum mechanics.

tgt_text: so what i'm telling you here is something truly fantastic.

tgt_text: what does it mean for one thing to be both vibrating and not vibrating at the same time?

tgt_text: so let's think about the atoms.

tgt_text: now it's only at precise times when they align.

tgt_text: the rest of the time they're delocalized.

tgt_text: in 2007, i decided that we needed to reconceptualize how we thought about economic development.
src_text: in 2007, i decided that we needed to reconceptualize how we thought about economic development.

tgt_text: our new goal should be that when every family thinks about where they want to live and work, they should be able to choose between at least a handful of different cities that were all competing to attract new residents.
src_text: our new goal should be that when every family thinks about where they want to live and work, they should be able to choose between at least a handful of different cities that were all competing to attract new residents.

tgt_text: now we're a long way away from that goal right now.
src_text: now we're a long way away from that goal right now.

tgt_text: there are billions of people in developing countries who don't have even a single city that would be willing to welcome them.
src_text: there are billions of people in developing countries who don't have even a single city that would be willing to welcome them.

tgt_text: but the amazing thing about cities is they're worth so much more than it costs to build them.
src_text: but the amazing thing about cities is they're worth so much more than it costs to build them.

tgt_text: so we could easily supply the world with dozens, maybe hundreds, of new cities.
src_text: so we could easily supply the world with dozens, maybe hundreds, of new cities.

tgt_text: now this might sound preposterous to you if you've never thought about new cities.
src_text: now this might sound preposterous to you if you've never thought about new cities.

tgt_text: but just substitute apartment building for cities.
src_text: but just substitute apartment building for cities.

tgt_text: imagine half the people who wanted to be in apartments already had them; the other half aren't there yet.
src_text: imagine half the people who wanted to be in apartments already had them; the other half aren't there yet.

tgt_text: you could try and expand the capacity by doing additions on all the existing apartments.
src_text: you could try and expand the capacity by doing additions on all the existing apartments.

tgt_text: but you know what you'd run into is those apartments and the surrounding areas have rules to avoid discomfort and the distractions of construction.
src_text: but you know what you'd run into is those apartments and the surrounding areas have rules to avoid discomfort and the distractions of construction.

tgt_text: so it's extremely hard to do all of those additions.
src_text: so it's extremely hard to do all of those additions.

tgt_text: but you could go out someplace brand new, build a brand new apartment building, as long as the rules there were ones that facilitated construction rather than getting in the way.
src_text: but you could go out someplace brand new, build a brand new apartment building, as long as the rules there were ones that facilitated construction rather than getting in the way.

tgt_text: so i proposed that governments create new reform zones big enough to hold cities and gave them a name: charter cities.
src_text: so i proposed that governments create new reform zones big enough to hold cities and gave them a name: charter cities.

tgt_text: later i learned that at about this same time, javier and octavio were thinking about the challenge of reform in honduras.
src_text: later i learned that at about this same time, javier and octavio were thinking about the challenge of reform in honduras.

tgt_text: they knew that about 75,000 hondurans every year would leave to go to the united states, and they wanted to ask, what could they do to make sure that those people could stay and do the same things in honduras.
src_text: they knew that about 75,000 hondurans every year would leave to go to the united states, and they wanted to ask, what could they do to make sure that those people could stay and do the same things in honduras.

tgt_text: at one point, javier said to octavio, "what if we took some of our empty land — what if we just gave it to an embassy — give some to the u.s. embassy; give some to the canadian embassy — and then if people want to go work under the rules of canada or under the rules of the united states, they can go get jobs, do everything they do on those embassy grounds that they would otherwise have to go to canada or the u.s. to do?"

tgt_text: so i wear two hats in most of what i do.

tgt_text: as the one hat, i do history of anatomy.
src_text: as the one hat, i do history of anatomy.

tgt_text: i'm a historian by training, and what i study in that case is the way that people have dealt with anatomy — meaning human bodies, animal bodies — how they dealt with bodily fluids, concepts of bodies; how have they thought about bodies.
src_text: i'm a historian by training, and what i study in that case is the way that people have dealt with anatomy — meaning human bodies, animal bodies — how they dealt with bodily fluids, concepts of bodies; how have they thought about bodies.

tgt_text: the other hat that i've worn in my work is as an activist, as a patient advocate — or, as i sometimes say, as an impatient advocate — for people who are patients of doctors.
src_text: the other hat that i've worn in my work is as an activist, as a patient advocate — or, as i sometimes say, as an impatient advocate — for people who are patients of doctors.

tgt_text: in that case, what i've worked with is people who have body types that challenge social norms.
src_text: in that case, what i've worked with is people who have body types that challenge social norms.

tgt_text: so some of what i've worked on, for example, is people who are conjoined twins — two people within one body.

tgt_text: some of what i've worked on is people who have dwarfism — so people who are much shorter than typical.
src_text: some of what i've worked on is people who have dwarfism — so people who are much shorter than typical.

tgt_text: and a lot of what i've worked on is people who have atypical sex — so people who don't have the standard male or the standard female body types.
src_text: and a lot of what i've worked on is people who have atypical sex — so people who don't have the standard male or the standard female body types.

tgt_text: and as a general term, we can use the term "intersex" for this.
src_text: and as a general term, we can use the term "intersex" for this.

tgt_text: intersex comes in a lot of different forms.
