tgt_text: i'll just give you a few examples of the types of ways you can have sex that isn't standard for male or female.
src_text: i'll just give you a few examples of the types of ways you can have sex that isn't standard for male or female.

tgt_text: so in one instance, you can have somebody who has an xy chromosomal basis, and that sry gene on the y chromosome tells the proto-gonads, which we all have in the fetal life, to become testes.
src_text: so in one instance, you can have somebody who has an xy chromosomal basis, and that sry gene on the y chromosome tells the proto-gonads, which we all have in the fetal life, to become testes.

tgt_text: so in the fetal life, those testes are pumping out testosterone.
src_text: so in the fetal life, those testes are pumping out testosterone.

tgt_text: but because this individual lacks receptors to hear that testosterone, the body doesn't react to the testosterone.
src_text: but because this individual lacks receptors to hear that testosterone, the body doesn't react to the testosterone.

tgt_text: and this is a syndrome called androgen insensitivity syndrome.
src_text: and this is a syndrome called androgen insensitivity syndrome.

tgt_text: so lots of levels of testosterone, but no reaction to it.
src_text: so lots of levels of testosterone, but no reaction to it.

tgt_text: as a consequence, the body develops more along the female typical path.
src_text: as a consequence, the body develops more along the female typical path.

tgt_text: when the child is born, she looks like a girl.
src_text: when the child is born, she looks like a girl.

tgt_text: she is a girl, she is raised as a girl.
src_text: she is a girl, she is raised as a girl.

tgt_text: and it's often not until she hits puberty and she's growing and developing breasts, but she's not getting her period, that somebody figures out something's up here.
src_text: and it's often not until she hits puberty and she's growing and developing breasts, but she's not getting her period, that somebody figures out something's up here.

tgt_text: and they do some tests and figure out that, instead of having ovaries inside and a uterus, she has testes inside, and she has a y chromosome.
src_text: and they do some tests and figure out that, instead of having ovaries inside and a uterus, she has testes inside, and she has a y chromosome.

tgt_text: now what's important to understand is you may think of this person as really being male, but they're really not.
src_text: now what's important to understand is you may think of this person as really being male, but they're really not.

tgt_text: females, like males, have in our bodies something called the adrenal glands.
src_text: females, like males, have in our bodies something called the adrenal glands.

tgt_text: they're in the back of our body.
src_text: they're in the back of our body.

tgt_text: and the adrenal glands make androgens, which are a masculinizing hormone.
src_text: and the adrenal glands make androgens, which are a masculinizing hormone.

tgt_text: most females like me — i believe myself to be a typical female — i don't actually know my chromosomal make-up, but i think i'm probably typical — most females like me are actually androgen-sensitive.
src_text: most females like me — i believe myself to be a typical female — i don't actually know my chromosomal make-up, but i think i'm probably typical — most females like me are actually androgen-sensitive.

tgt_text: we're making androgen, and we're responding to androgens.
src_text: we're making androgen, and we're responding to androgens.

tgt_text: the consequence is that somebody like me has actually had a brain exposed to more androgens than the woman born with testes who has androgen insensitivity syndrome.
src_text: the consequence is that somebody like me has actually had a brain exposed to more androgens than the woman born with testes who has androgen insensitivity syndrome.

tgt_text: so sex is really complicated — it's not just that intersex people are in the middle of all the sex spectrum — in some ways, they can be all over the place.
src_text: so sex is really complicated — it's not just that intersex people are in the middle of all the sex spectrum — in some ways, they can be all over the place.

tgt_text: another example: a few years ago i got a call from a man who was 19 years old, who was born a boy, raised a boy, had a girlfriend, had sex with his girlfriend, had a life as a guy, and had just found out that he had ovaries and a uterus inside.
src_text: another example: a few years ago i got a call from a man who was 19 years old, who was born a boy, raised a boy, had a girlfriend, had sex with his girlfriend, had a life as a guy, and had just found out that he had ovaries and a uterus inside.

tgt_text: what he had was an extreme form of a condition called congenital adrenal hyperplasia.
src_text: what he had was an extreme form of a condition called congenital adrenal hyperplasia.

tgt_text: he had xx chromosomes, and in the womb, his adrenal glands were in such high gear that it created, essentially, a masculine hormonal environment.
src_text: he had xx chromosomes, and in the womb, his adrenal glands were in such high gear that it created, essentially, a masculine hormonal environment.

tgt_text: and as a consequence, his genitals were masculinized, his brain was subject to the more typical masculine component of hormones.
src_text: and as a consequence, his genitals were masculinized, his brain was subject to the more typical masculine component of hormones.

tgt_text: and he was born looking like a boy — nobody suspected anything.
src_text: and he was born looking like a boy — nobody suspected anything.

tgt_text: and it was only when he had reached the age of 19 that he began to have enough medical problems from menstruating internally, that doctors figured out that, in fact, he was female, internally.
src_text: and it was only when he had reached the age of 19 that he began to have enough medical problems from menstruating internally, that doctors figured out that, in fact, he was female, internally.

tgt_text: ok, so just one more quick example of a way you can have intersex.
src_text: ok, so just one more quick example of a way you can have intersex.

tgt_text: some people who have xx chromosomes develop what are called ovotestis, which is when you have ovarian tissue with testicular tissue wrapped around it.
src_text: some people who have xx chromosomes develop what are called ovotestis, which is when you have ovarian tissue with testicular tissue wrapped around it.

tgt_text: and we're not exactly sure why that happens.
src_text: and we're not exactly sure why that happens.

tgt_text: so sex can come in lots of different varieties.
src_text: so sex can come in lots of different varieties.

tgt_text: the reason that children with these kinds of bodies — whether it's dwarfism, or it's conjoined twinning, or it's an intersex type — are often "normalized" by surgeons is not because it actually leaves them better off in terms of physical health.
src_text: the reason that children with these kinds of bodies — whether it's dwarfism, or it's conjoined twinning, or it's an intersex type — are often "normalized" by surgeons is not because it actually leaves them better off in terms of physical health.

tgt_text: in many cases, people are actually perfectly healthy.
src_text: in many cases, people are actually perfectly healthy.

tgt_text: the reason they're often subject to various kinds of surgeries is because they threaten our social categories.
src_text: the reason they're often subject to various kinds of surgeries is because they threaten our social categories.

tgt_text: our system has been based typically on the idea that a particular kind of anatomy comes with a particular identity.
src_text: our system has been based typically on the idea that a particular kind of anatomy comes with a particular identity.

tgt_text: so we have the concept that what it means to be a woman is to have a female identity; what it means to be a black person is, allegedly, to have an african anatomy in terms of your history.
src_text: so we have the concept that what it means to be a woman is to have a female identity; what it means to be a black person is, allegedly, to have an african anatomy in terms of your history.

tgt_text: and so we have this terribly simplistic idea.
src_text: and so we have this terribly simplistic idea.

tgt_text: and when we're faced with a body that actually presents us something quite different, it startles us in terms of those categorizations.
src_text: and when we're faced with a body that actually presents us something quite different, it startles us in terms of those categorizations.

tgt_text: so we have a lot of very romantic ideas in our culture about individualism.
src_text: so we have a lot of very romantic ideas in our culture about individualism.

tgt_text: and our nation's really founded on a very romantic concept of individualism.
src_text: and our nation's really founded on a very romantic concept of individualism.

tgt_text: you can imagine how startling then it is when you have children who are born who are two people inside of one body. where i ran into the most heat from this most recently was last year when south african runner, caster semenya, had her sex called into question at the international games in berlin.
src_text: you can imagine how startling then it is when you have children who are born who are two people inside of one body. where i ran into the most heat from this most recently was last year when south african runner, caster semenya, had her sex called into question at the international games in berlin.

tgt_text: i had a lot of journalists calling me, asking me, "which is the test they're going to run that will tell us whether or not caster semenya is male or female?" and i had to explain to the journalists there isn't such a test.
src_text: i had a lot of journalists calling me, asking me, "which is the test they're going to run that will tell us whether or not caster semenya is male or female?" and i had to explain to the journalists there isn't such a test.

tgt_text: in fact, we now know that sex is complicated enough that we have to admit: nature doesn't draw the line for us between male and female, or between male and intersex and female and intersex; we actually draw that line on nature.
src_text: in fact, we now know that sex is complicated enough that we have to admit: nature doesn't draw the line for us between male and female, or between male and intersex and female and intersex; we actually draw that line on nature.

tgt_text: so what we have is a sort of situation where the farther our science goes, the more we have to admit to ourselves that these categories that we thought of as stable anatomical categories, that mapped very simply to stable identity categories are a lot more fuzzy than we thought.
src_text: so what we have is a sort of situation where the farther our science goes, the more we have to admit to ourselves that these categories that we thought of as stable anatomical categories, that mapped very simply to stable identity categories are a lot more fuzzy than we thought.

tgt_text: and it's not just in terms of sex.
src_text: and it's not just in terms of sex.

tgt_text: it's also in terms of race, which turns out to be vastly more complicated than our terminology has allowed.
src_text: it's also in terms of race, which turns out to be vastly more complicated than our terminology has allowed.

tgt_text: as we look, we get into all sorts of uncomfortable areas.
src_text: as we look, we get into all sorts of uncomfortable areas.

tgt_text: we look, for example, about the fact that we share at least 95 percent of our dna with chimpanzees.
src_text: we look, for example, about the fact that we share at least 95 percent of our dna with chimpanzees.

tgt_text: what are we to make of the fact that we differ from them only, really, by a few nucleotides?
src_text: what are we to make of the fact that we differ from them only, really, by a few nucleotides?

tgt_text: and as we get farther and farther with our science, we get more and more into a discomforted zone, where we have to acknowledge that the simplistic categories we've had are probably overly simplistic.
src_text: and as we get farther and farther with our science, we get more and more into a discomforted zone, where we have to acknowledge that the simplistic categories we've had are probably overly simplistic.

tgt_text: so we're seeing this in all sorts of places in human life.
src_text: so we're seeing this in all sorts of places in human life.

tgt_text: one of the places we're seeing it, for example, in our culture, in the united states today, is battles over the beginning of life and the end of life.
src_text: one of the places we're seeing it, for example, in our culture, in the united states today, is battles over the beginning of life and the end of life.

tgt_text: we have difficult conversations about at what point we decide a body becomes a human, such that it has a different right than a fetal life.
src_text: we have difficult conversations about at what point we decide a body becomes a human, such that it has a different right than a fetal life.

tgt_text: we have very difficult conversations nowadays — probably not out in the open as much as within medicine — about the question of when somebody's dead.
src_text: we have very difficult conversations nowadays — probably not out in the open as much as within medicine — about the question of when somebody's dead.

tgt_text: in the past, our ancestors never had to struggle so much with this question of when somebody was dead.
src_text: in the past, our ancestors never had to struggle so much with this question of when somebody was dead.

tgt_text: at most, they'd stick a feather on somebody's nose, and if it twitched, they didn't bury them yet.
src_text: at most, they'd stick a feather on somebody's nose, and if it twitched, they didn't bury them yet.

tgt_text: if it stopped twitching, you bury them.

tgt_text: but today, we have a situation where we want to take vital organs out of beings and give them to other beings.
src_text: but today, we have a situation where we want to take vital organs out of beings and give them to other beings.

tgt_text: and as a consequence, we have to struggle with this really difficult question about who's dead, and this leads us to a really difficult situation where we don't have such simple categories as we've had before.
src_text: and as a consequence, we have to struggle with this really difficult question about who's dead, and this leads us to a really difficult situation where we don't have such simple categories as we've had before.

tgt_text: now you might think that all this breaking-down of categories would make somebody like me really happy.

tgt_text: i'm a political progressive, i defend people with unusual bodies, but i have to admit to you that it makes me nervous.

tgt_text: understanding that these categories are really much more unstable than we thought makes me tense.

tgt_text: it makes me tense from the point of view of thinking about democracy.

tgt_text: so in order to tell you about that tension, i have to first admit to you a huge fan of the founding fathers.

tgt_text: i know they were racists, i know they were sexist, but they were great.

tgt_text: i mean, they were so brave and so bold and so radical in what they did, that i find myself watching that cheesy musical "1776" every few years, and it's not because of the music, which is totally forgettable.

tgt_text: it's because of what happened in 1776 with the founding fathers.

tgt_text: the founding fathers were, for my point of view, the original anatomical activists, and this is why.
src_text: the founding fathers were, for my point of view, the original anatomical activists, and this is why.

tgt_text: what they rejected was an anatomical concept and replaced it with another one that was radical and beautiful and held us for 200 years.

tgt_text: so as you all recall, what our founding fathers were rejecting was a concept of monarchy, and the monarchy was basically based on a very simplistic concept of anatomy.
src_text: so as you all recall, what our founding fathers were rejecting was a concept of monarchy, and the monarchy was basically based on a very simplistic concept of anatomy.

tgt_text: the monarchs of the old world didn't have a concept of dna, but they did have a concept of birthright.

tgt_text: they had a concept of blue blood.

tgt_text: they had the idea that the people who would be in political power should be in political power because of the blood being passed down from grandfather to father to son and so forth.
src_text: they had the idea that the people who would be in political power should be in political power because of the blood being passed down from grandfather to father to son and so forth.

tgt_text: the founding fathers rejected that idea, and they replaced it with a new anatomical concept, and that concept was "all men are created equal." they leveled that playing field and decided the anatomy that mattered was the commonality of anatomy, not the difference in anatomy, and that was a really radical thing to do.
src_text: the founding fathers rejected that idea, and they replaced it with a new anatomical concept, and that concept was "all men are created equal." they leveled that playing field and decided the anatomy that mattered was the commonality of anatomy, not the difference in anatomy, and that was a really radical thing to do.

tgt_text: now they were doing it in part because they were part of an enlightenment system where two things were growing up together.

tgt_text: and that was democracy growing up, but it was also science growing up at the same time.

tgt_text: and it's really clear, if you look at the history of the founding fathers, a lot of them were very interested in science, and they were interested in the concept of a naturalistic world.

tgt_text: they were moving away from supernatural explanations, and they were rejecting things like a supernatural concept of power, where it transmitted because of a very vague concept of birthright.

tgt_text: and if you look, for example, in the declaration of independence, they talk about nature and nature's god.

tgt_text: and in doing so, they were really setting up in a beautiful way the civil rights movement of the future.

tgt_text: so what happened years afterwards?

tgt_text: what happened was women, for example, who wanted the right to vote, took the founding fathers' concept of anatomical commonality being more important than anatomical difference and said, "the fact that we have a uterus and ovaries is not significant enough in terms of a difference to mean that we shouldn't have the right to vote, the right to full citizenship, the right to own property, etc." and women successfully argued that.

tgt_text: next came the successful civil rights movement, where we found people like sojourner truth talking about, "ain't i a woman?" we find men on the marching lines of the civil rights movement saying, "i am a man." again, people of color appealing to a commonality of anatomy over a difference of anatomy, again, successfully.

tgt_text: so we have these anatomical categories that persist, that are in many ways problematic and questionable.

tgt_text: and the question to me becomes: what do we do, as our science gets to be so good in looking at anatomy, that we reach the point where we have to admit that a democracy that's been based on anatomy might start falling apart?

tgt_text: so whereas the fathers were extremely attentive to figuring out how to protect individuals from the state, it's possible that if we injected more mothers into this concept, what we would have is more of a concept of not just how to protect, but how to care for each other.

tgt_text: do you know how many choices you make in a typical day?

tgt_text: i recently did a survey with over 2,000 americans, and the average number of choices that the typical american reports making is about 70 in a typical day. there was also recently a study done with ceos in which they followed ceos around for a whole week.

tgt_text: and these scientists simply documented all the various tasks that these ceos engaged in and how much time they spent engaging in making decisions related to these tasks.

tgt_text: today i want to talk about one of the biggest modern day choosing problems that we have, which is the choice overload problem.

tgt_text: so when i was a graduate student at stanford university, i used to go to this very, very upscale grocery store; at least at that time it was truly upscale.
src_text: so when i was a graduate student at stanford university, i used to go to this very, very upscale grocery store; at least at that time it was truly upscale.

tgt_text: it was a store called draeger's.
src_text: it was a store called draeger's.

tgt_text: now this store, it was almost like going to an amusement park.
src_text: now this store, it was almost like going to an amusement park.

tgt_text: they had 250 different kinds of mustards and vinegars and over 500 different kinds of fruits and vegetables and more than two dozen different kinds of bottled water — and this was during a time when we actually used to drink tap water.
src_text: they had 250 different kinds of mustards and vinegars and over 500 different kinds of fruits and vegetables and more than two dozen different kinds of bottled water — and this was during a time when we actually used to drink tap water.

tgt_text: i used to love going to this store, but on one occasion i asked myself, well how come you never buy anything?
src_text: i used to love going to this store, but on one occasion i asked myself, well how come you never buy anything?

tgt_text: here's their olive oil aisle.
src_text: here's their olive oil aisle.

tgt_text: they had over 75 different kinds of olive oil, including those that were in a locked case that came from thousand-year-old olive trees.
src_text: they had over 75 different kinds of olive oil, including those that were in a locked case that came from thousand-year-old olive trees.

tgt_text: so i one day decided to pay a visit to the manager, and i asked the manager, "is this model of offering people all this choice really working?" and he pointed to the busloads of tourists that would show up everyday, with cameras ready usually.
src_text: so i one day decided to pay a visit to the manager, and i asked the manager, "is this model of offering people all this choice really working?" and he pointed to the busloads of tourists that would show up everyday, with cameras ready usually.

tgt_text: we decided to do a little experiment, and we picked jam for our experiment.
src_text: we decided to do a little experiment, and we picked jam for our experiment.

tgt_text: here's their jam aisle.
src_text: here's their jam aisle.

tgt_text: they had 348 different kinds of jam.
src_text: they had 348 different kinds of jam.

tgt_text: we set up a little tasting booth right near the entrance of the store.
src_text: we set up a little tasting booth right near the entrance of the store.

tgt_text: we there put out six different flavors of jam or 24 different flavors of jam, and we looked at two things: first, in which case were people more likely to stop, sample some jam?
src_text: we there put out six different flavors of jam or 24 different flavors of jam, and we looked at two things: first, in which case were people more likely to stop, sample some jam?

tgt_text: more people stopped when there were 24, about 60 percent, than when there were six, about 40 percent.
src_text: more people stopped when there were 24, about 60 percent, than when there were six, about 40 percent.

tgt_text: the next thing we looked at is in which case were people more likely to buy a jar of jam.
src_text: the next thing we looked at is in which case were people more likely to buy a jar of jam.

tgt_text: now we see the opposite effect.
src_text: now we see the opposite effect.

tgt_text: of the people who stopped when there were 24, only three percent of them actually bought a jar of jam.
src_text: of the people who stopped when there were 24, only three percent of them actually bought a jar of jam.

tgt_text: of the people who stopped when there were six, well now we saw that 30 percent of them actually bought a jar of jam.
src_text: of the people who stopped when there were six, well now we saw that 30 percent of them actually bought a jar of jam.

tgt_text: now if you do the math, people were at least six times more likely to buy a jar of jam if they encountered six than if they encountered 24.
src_text: now if you do the math, people were at least six times more likely to buy a jar of jam if they encountered six than if they encountered 24.

tgt_text: now choosing not to buy a jar of jam is probably good for us — at least it's good for our waistlines — but it turns out that this choice overload problem affects us even in very consequential decisions.
src_text: now choosing not to buy a jar of jam is probably good for us — at least it's good for our waistlines — but it turns out that this choice overload problem affects us even in very consequential decisions.

tgt_text: we choose not to choose, even when it goes against our best self-interests.
src_text: we choose not to choose, even when it goes against our best self-interests.

tgt_text: so now for the topic of today: financial savings.
src_text: so now for the topic of today: financial savings.

tgt_text: now i'm going to describe to you a study i did with gur huberman, emir kamenica, wei jang where we looked at the retirement savings decisions of nearly a million americans from about 650 plans all in the u.s. and what we looked at was whether the number of fund offerings available in a retirement savings plan, the 401 (k) plan, does that affect people's likelihood to save more for tomorrow.
src_text: now i'm going to describe to you a study i did with gur huberman, emir kamenica, wei jang where we looked at the retirement savings decisions of nearly a million americans from about 650 plans all in the u.s. and what we looked at was whether the number of fund offerings available in a retirement savings plan, the 401 (k) plan, does that affect people's likelihood to save more for tomorrow.

tgt_text: and what we found was that indeed there was a correlation.
src_text: and what we found was that indeed there was a correlation.

tgt_text: so in these plans, we had about 657 plans that ranged from offering people anywhere from two to 59 different fund offerings.
src_text: so in these plans, we had about 657 plans that ranged from offering people anywhere from two to 59 different fund offerings.

tgt_text: and what we found was that, the more funds offered, indeed, there was less participation rate.
src_text: and what we found was that, the more funds offered, indeed, there was less participation rate.

tgt_text: so if you look at the extremes, those plans that offered you two funds, participation rates were around in the mid-70s — still not as high as we want it to be.
src_text: so if you look at the extremes, those plans that offered you two funds, participation rates were around in the mid-70s — still not as high as we want it to be.

tgt_text: in those plans that offered nearly 60 funds, participation rates have now dropped to about the 60th percentile.
src_text: in those plans that offered nearly 60 funds, participation rates have now dropped to about the 60th percentile.

tgt_text: now it turns out that even if you do choose to participate when there are more choices present, even then, it has negative consequences.
src_text: now it turns out that even if you do choose to participate when there are more choices present, even then, it has negative consequences.

tgt_text: so for those people who did choose to participate, the more choices available, the more likely people were to completely avoid stocks or equity funds.
src_text: so for those people who did choose to participate, the more choices available, the more likely people were to completely avoid stocks or equity funds.

tgt_text: the more choices available, the more likely they were to put all their money in pure money market accounts.
src_text: the more choices available, the more likely they were to put all their money in pure money market accounts.

tgt_text: now neither of these extreme decisions are the kinds of decisions that any of us would recommend for people when you're considering their future financial well-being.

tgt_text: well, over the past decade, we have observed three main negative consequences to offering people more and more choices.

tgt_text: they're more likely to delay choosing — procrastinate even when it goes against their best self-interest.

tgt_text: they're more likely to make worse choices — worse financial choices, medical choices.

tgt_text: they're more likely to choose things that make them less satisfied, even when they do objectively better.

tgt_text: the main reason for this is because, we might enjoy gazing at those giant walls of mayonnaises, mustards, vinegars, jams, but we can't actually do the math of comparing and contrasting and actually picking from that stunning display.

tgt_text: so what i want to propose to you today are four simple techniques — techniques that we have tested in one way or another in different research venues — that you can easily apply in your businesses.

tgt_text: the first: cut. you've heard it said before, but it's never been more true than today, that less is more.

tgt_text: but in fact, what we're seeing more and more is that if you are willing to cut, get rid of those extraneous redundant options, well there's an increase in sales, there's a lowering of costs, there is an improvement of the choosing experience.

tgt_text: which brings me to the second technique for handling the choice overload problem, which is concretization.

tgt_text: that in order for people to understand the differences between the choices, they have to be able to understand the consequences associated with each choice, and that the consequences need to be felt in a vivid sort of way, in a very concrete way.

tgt_text: so a study that i did with shlomo benartzi and alessandro previtero, we did a study with people at ing — employees that are all working at ing — and now these people were all in a session where they're doing enrollment for their 401 (k) plan.

tgt_text: so let me recap. i have talked about four techniques for mitigating the problem of choice overload — cut — get rid of the extraneous alternatives; concretize — make it real; categorize — we can handle more categories, less choices; condition for complexity.

tgt_text: two years later i was an attending in the emergency department at a community hospital just north of toronto, and i saw a 25 year-old man with a sore throat.
src_text: two years later i was an attending in the emergency department at a community hospital just north of toronto, and i saw a 25 year-old man with a sore throat.

tgt_text: and she said the three words: do you remember? "do you remember that patient you saw with the sore throat?" well it turns out, he didn't have a strep throat.

tgt_text: he had a potentially life-threatening condition called epiglottitis.

tgt_text: here's the problem: if i can't come clean and talk about my mistakes, if i can't find the still-small voice that tells me what really happened, how can i share it with my colleagues?
src_text: here's the problem: if i can't come clean and talk about my mistakes, if i can't find the still-small voice that tells me what really happened, how can i share it with my colleagues?

tgt_text: if i were to walk into a room filled with my colleages and ask for their support right now and start to tell what i've just told you right now, i probably wouldn't get through two of those stories before they would start to get really uncomfortable, somebody would crack a joke, they'd change the subject and we would move on.

tgt_text: that's the system that we have.
src_text: that's the system that we have.

tgt_text: it's a complete denial of mistakes.
src_text: it's a complete denial of mistakes.

tgt_text: it's a system in which there are two kinds of physicians — those who make mistakes and those who don't, those who can't handle sleep deprivation and those who can, those who have lousy outcomes and those who have great outcomes.
src_text: it's a system in which there are two kinds of physicians — those who make mistakes and those who don't, those who can't handle sleep deprivation and those who can, those who have lousy outcomes and those who have great outcomes.

tgt_text: and it's almost like an ideological reaction, like the antibodies begin to attack that person.
src_text: and it's almost like an ideological reaction, like the antibodies begin to attack that person.

tgt_text: and we have this idea that if we drive the people who make mistakes out of medicine, what will we be left with, but a safe system.
src_text: and we have this idea that if we drive the people who make mistakes out of medicine, what will we be left with, but a safe system.

tgt_text: but there are two problems with that.
src_text: but there are two problems with that.

tgt_text: in my 20 years or so of medical broadcasting and journalism, i've made a personal study of medical malpractice and medical errors to learn everything i can, from one of the first articles i wrote for the toronto star to my show "white coat, black art." and what i've learned is that errors are absolutely ubiquitous.
src_text: in my 20 years or so of medical broadcasting and journalism, i've made a personal study of medical malpractice and medical errors to learn everything i can, from one of the first articles i wrote for the toronto star to my show "white coat, black art." and what i've learned is that errors are absolutely ubiquitous.

tgt_text: we work in a system where errors happen every day, where one in 10 medications are either the wrong medication given in hospital or at the wrong dosage, where hospital-acquired infections are getting more and more numerous, causing havoc and death.
src_text: we work in a system where errors happen every day, where one in 10 medications are either the wrong medication given in hospital or at the wrong dosage, where hospital-acquired infections are getting more and more numerous, causing havoc and death.

tgt_text: in this country, as many as 24,000 canadians die of preventable medical errors.
src_text: in this country, as many as 24,000 canadians die of preventable medical errors.

tgt_text: in the united states, the institute of medicine pegged it at 100,000.
src_text: in the united states, the institute of medicine pegged it at 100,000.

tgt_text: in both cases, these are gross underestimates, because we really aren't ferreting out the problem as we should.
src_text: in both cases, these are gross underestimates, because we really aren't ferreting out the problem as we should.

tgt_text: and here's the thing.
src_text: and here's the thing.

tgt_text: in a hospital system where medical knowledge is doubling every two or three years, we can't keep up with it. sleep deprivation is absolutely pervasive. we can't get rid of it.
src_text: in a hospital system where medical knowledge is doubling every two or three years, we can't keep up with it. sleep deprivation is absolutely pervasive. we can't get rid of it.

tgt_text: we have our cognitive biases, so that i can take a perfect history on a patient with chest pain.
src_text: we have our cognitive biases, so that i can take a perfect history on a patient with chest pain.

tgt_text: now take the same patient with chest pain, make them moist and garrulous and put a little bit of alcohol on their breath, and suddenly my history is laced with contempt.
src_text: now take the same patient with chest pain, make them moist and garrulous and put a little bit of alcohol on their breath, and suddenly my history is laced with contempt.

tgt_text: i don't take the same history.
src_text: i don't take the same history.

tgt_text: i'm not a robot; i don't do things the same way each time.
src_text: i'm not a robot; i don't do things the same way each time.

tgt_text: and my patients aren't cars; they don't tell me their symptoms in the same way each time. given all of that, mistakes are inevitable.
src_text: and my patients aren't cars; they don't tell me their symptoms in the same way each time. given all of that, mistakes are inevitable.

tgt_text: so if you take the system, as i was taught, and weed out all the error-prone health professionals, well there won't be anybody left.
src_text: so if you take the system, as i was taught, and weed out all the error-prone health professionals, well there won't be anybody left.

tgt_text: and you know that business about people not wanting to talk about their worst cases?
src_text: and you know that business about people not wanting to talk about their worst cases?

tgt_text: on my show, on "white coat, black art," i made it a habit of saying, "here's my worst mistake," i would say to everybody from paramedics to the chief of cardiac surgery, "here's my worst mistake," blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, "what about yours?" and i would point the microphone towards them.
src_text: on my show, on "white coat, black art," i made it a habit of saying, "here's my worst mistake," i would say to everybody from paramedics to the chief of cardiac surgery, "here's my worst mistake," blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, "what about yours?" and i would point the microphone towards them.

tgt_text: and their pupils would dilate, they would recoil, then they would look down and swallow hard and start to tell me their stories.
src_text: and their pupils would dilate, they would recoil, then they would look down and swallow hard and start to tell me their stories.

tgt_text: they want to tell their stories.
src_text: they want to tell their stories.

tgt_text: they want to share their stories.
src_text: they want to share their stories.

tgt_text: they want to be able to say, "look, don't make the same mistake i did." what they need is an environment to be able to do that.
src_text: they want to be able to say, "look, don't make the same mistake i did." what they need is an environment to be able to do that.

tgt_text: what they need is a redefined medical culture.
src_text: what they need is a redefined medical culture.

tgt_text: and it starts with one physician at a time.
src_text: and it starts with one physician at a time.

tgt_text: the redefined physician is human, knows she's human, accepts it, isn't proud of making mistakes, but strives to learn one thing from what happened that she can teach to somebody else.
src_text: the redefined physician is human, knows she's human, accepts it, isn't proud of making mistakes, but strives to learn one thing from what happened that she can teach to somebody else.

tgt_text: she shares her experience with others.
src_text: she shares her experience with others.

tgt_text: she's supportive when other people talk about their mistakes.
src_text: she's supportive when other people talk about their mistakes.

tgt_text: and she points out other people's mistakes, not in a gotcha way, but in a loving, supportive way so that everybody can benefit.
src_text: and she points out other people's mistakes, not in a gotcha way, but in a loving, supportive way so that everybody can benefit.

tgt_text: and she works in a culture of medicine that acknowledges that human beings run the system, and when human beings run the system, they will make mistakes from time to time.
src_text: and she works in a culture of medicine that acknowledges that human beings run the system, and when human beings run the system, they will make mistakes from time to time.

tgt_text: so the system is evolving to create backups that make it easier to detect those mistakes that humans inevitably make and also fosters in a loving, supportive way places where everybody who is observing in the health care system can actually point out things that could be potential mistakes and is rewarded for doing so, and especially people like me, when we do make mistakes, we're rewarded for coming clean.
src_text: so the system is evolving to create backups that make it easier to detect those mistakes that humans inevitably make and also fosters in a loving, supportive way places where everybody who is observing in the health care system can actually point out things that could be potential mistakes and is rewarded for doing so, and especially people like me, when we do make mistakes, we're rewarded for coming clean.

tgt_text: my name is brian goldman.
src_text: my name is brian goldman.

tgt_text: i am a redefined physician. i'm human. i make mistakes. i'm sorry about that, but i strive to learn one thing that i can pass on to other people.
src_text: i am a redefined physician. i'm human. i make mistakes. i'm sorry about that, but i strive to learn one thing that i can pass on to other people.

tgt_text: i still don't know what you think of me, but i can live with that.
src_text: i still don't know what you think of me, but i can live with that.

tgt_text: and let me close with three words of my own: i do remember. (applause)
src_text: and let me close with three words of my own: i do remember. (applause)

tgt_text: because i usually take the role of trying to explain to people how wonderful the new technologies that are coming along are going to be, and i thought that, since i was among friends here, i would tell you what i really think and try to look back and try to understand what is really going on here with these amazing jumps in technology that seem so fast that we can barely keep on top of it.

src_text: so we've all heard about fairies and we've all heard about nymphs, but how many people outside of india know about their indian counterparts, the apsaras?

tgt_text: these poor apsaras have been trapped inside indra's chambers for thousands of years in an old and musty book.
src_text: these poor apsaras have been trapped inside indra's chambers for thousands of years in an old and musty book.

tgt_text: and so we're bringing them back in a contemporary story for children.
src_text: and so we're bringing them back in a contemporary story for children.

tgt_text: and a story that actually deals with new issues like the environmental crisis. (music)
src_text: and a story that actually deals with new issues like the environmental crisis. (music)

tgt_text: speaking of the environmental crisis, i think a big problem has been in the last 10 years is that children have been locked inside their rooms, glued to their pcs, they haven't been able to get out.
src_text: speaking of the environmental crisis, i think a big problem has been in the last 10 years is that children have been locked inside their rooms, glued to their pcs, they haven't been able to get out.

tgt_text: but now with mobile technology, we can actually take our children outside into the natural world with their technology.
src_text: but now with mobile technology, we can actually take our children outside into the natural world with their technology.

tgt_text: one of the interactions in the book is that you're sent off on this quest where you need to go outside, take out your camera on the ipad and collect pictures of different natural objects.
src_text: one of the interactions in the book is that you're sent off on this quest where you need to go outside, take out your camera on the ipad and collect pictures of different natural objects.

tgt_text: when i was a child, i had multiple collections of sticks and stones and pebbles and shells.
src_text: when i was a child, i had multiple collections of sticks and stones and pebbles and shells.

tgt_text: and somehow kids don't do that anymore.
src_text: and somehow kids don't do that anymore.

tgt_text: so in bringing back this childhood ritual, you need to go out and, in one chapter, take a picture of a flower and then tag it.
src_text: so in bringing back this childhood ritual, you need to go out and, in one chapter, take a picture of a flower and then tag it.

tgt_text: in another chapter, you need to take a picture of a piece of bark and then tag that.
src_text: in another chapter, you need to take a picture of a piece of bark and then tag that.

tgt_text: and what happens is that you actually create a digital collection of photographs that you can then put up online.
src_text: and what happens is that you actually create a digital collection of photographs that you can then put up online.

tgt_text: a child in london puts up a picture of a fox and says, "oh, i saw a fox today." a child in india says, "i saw a monkey today." and it creates this kind of social network around a collection of digital photographs that you've actually taken.
src_text: a child in london puts up a picture of a fox and says, "oh, i saw a fox today." a child in india says, "i saw a monkey today." and it creates this kind of social network around a collection of digital photographs that you've actually taken.

tgt_text: in the possibilities of linking together magic, the earth and technology, there are multiple possibilities.
src_text: in the possibilities of linking together magic, the earth and technology, there are multiple possibilities.

tgt_text: in the next book, we plan on having an interaction where you take your ipad out with the video on and through augmented reality, you see this layer of animated pixies appear on a houseplant that's outside your house.
src_text: in the next book, we plan on having an interaction where you take your ipad out with the video on and through augmented reality, you see this layer of animated pixies appear on a houseplant that's outside your house.

tgt_text: at one point, your screen is filled up with leaves.
src_text: at one point, your screen is filled up with leaves.

tgt_text: and so you need to make the sound of wind and blow them away and read the rest of the book.
src_text: and so you need to make the sound of wind and blow them away and read the rest of the book.

tgt_text: we're moving, we're all moving here, to a world where the forces of nature come closer together to technology, and magic and technology can come closer together.
src_text: we're moving, we're all moving here, to a world where the forces of nature come closer together to technology, and magic and technology can come closer together.

tgt_text: we're harnessing energy from the sun.
src_text: we're harnessing energy from the sun.

tgt_text: we're bringing our children and ourselves closer to the natural world and that magic and joy and childhood love that we had through the simple medium of a story.
src_text: we're bringing our children and ourselves closer to the natural world and that magic and joy and childhood love that we had through the simple medium of a story.

tgt_text: thank you.
src_text: thank you.

tgt_text: how can i speak in 10 minutes about the bonds of women over three generations, about how the astonishing strength of those bonds took hold in the life of a four-year-old girl huddled with her young sister, her mother and her grandmother for five days and nights in a small boat in the china sea more than 30 years ago.
src_text: how can i speak in 10 minutes about the bonds of women over three generations, about how the astonishing strength of those bonds took hold in the life of a four-year-old girl huddled with her young sister, her mother and her grandmother for five days and nights in a small boat in the china sea more than 30 years ago.

tgt_text: bonds that took hold in the life of that small girl and never let go — that small girl now living in san francisco and speaking to you today.
src_text: bonds that took hold in the life of that small girl and never let go — that small girl now living in san francisco and speaking to you today.

tgt_text: this is not a finished story.
src_text: this is not a finished story.

tgt_text: it is a jigsaw puzzle still being put together.
src_text: it is a jigsaw puzzle still being put together.

tgt_text: let me tell you about some of the pieces.
src_text: let me tell you about some of the pieces.

tgt_text: imagine the first piece: a man burning his life's work.
src_text: imagine the first piece: a man burning his life's work.

tgt_text: he is a poet, a playwright, a man whose whole life had been balanced on the single hope of his country's unity and freedom.
src_text: he is a poet, a playwright, a man whose whole life had been balanced on the single hope of his country's unity and freedom.

tgt_text: imagine him as the communists enter saigon — confronting the fact that his life had been a complete waste.
src_text: imagine him as the communists enter saigon — confronting the fact that his life had been a complete waste.

tgt_text: words, for so long his friends, now mocked him.
src_text: words, for so long his friends, now mocked him.

tgt_text: he retreated into silence.
src_text: he retreated into silence.

tgt_text: he died broken by history.
src_text: he died broken by history.

tgt_text: he is my grandfather.
src_text: he is my grandfather.

tgt_text: i never knew him in real life.
src_text: i never knew him in real life.

tgt_text: but our lives are much more than our memories.
src_text: but our lives are much more than our memories.

tgt_text: my grandmother never let me forget his life.
src_text: my grandmother never let me forget his life.

tgt_text: my duty was not to allow it to have been in vain, and my lesson was to learn that, yes, history tried to crush us, but we endured.
src_text: my duty was not to allow it to have been in vain, and my lesson was to learn that, yes, history tried to crush us, but we endured.

tgt_text: the next piece of the jigsaw is of a boat in the early dawn slipping silently out to sea.
src_text: the next piece of the jigsaw is of a boat in the early dawn slipping silently out to sea.

tgt_text: my mother, mai, was 18 when her father died — already in an arranged marriage, already with two small girls.
src_text: my mother, mai, was 18 when her father died — already in an arranged marriage, already with two small girls.

tgt_text: for her, life had distilled itself into one task: the escape of her family and a new life in australia.
src_text: for her, life had distilled itself into one task: the escape of her family and a new life in australia.

tgt_text: it was inconceivable to her that she would not succeed.
src_text: it was inconceivable to her that she would not succeed.

tgt_text: so after a four-year saga that defies fiction, a boat slipped out to sea disguised as a fishing vessel.
src_text: so after a four-year saga that defies fiction, a boat slipped out to sea disguised as a fishing vessel.

tgt_text: all the adults knew the risks.
src_text: all the adults knew the risks.

tgt_text: the greatest fear was of pirates, rape and death.
src_text: the greatest fear was of pirates, rape and death.

tgt_text: like most adults on the boat, my mother carried a small bottle of poison.
src_text: like most adults on the boat, my mother carried a small bottle of poison.

tgt_text: if we were captured, first my sister and i, then she and my grandmother would drink.
src_text: if we were captured, first my sister and i, then she and my grandmother would drink.

tgt_text: my first memories are from the boat — the steady beat of the engine, the bow dipping into each wave, the vast and empty horizon.
src_text: my first memories are from the boat — the steady beat of the engine, the bow dipping into each wave, the vast and empty horizon.

tgt_text: i don't remember the pirates who came many times, but were bluffed by the bravado of the men on our boat, or the engine dying and failing to start for six hours.
src_text: i don't remember the pirates who came many times, but were bluffed by the bravado of the men on our boat, or the engine dying and failing to start for six hours.

tgt_text: but i do remember the lights on the oil rig off the malaysian coast and the young man who collapsed and died, the journey's end too much for him, and the first apple i tasted, given to me by the men on the rig.
src_text: but i do remember the lights on the oil rig off the malaysian coast and the young man who collapsed and died, the journey's end too much for him, and the first apple i tasted, given to me by the men on the rig.

tgt_text: no apple has ever tasted the same.
src_text: no apple has ever tasted the same.

tgt_text: after three months in a refugee camp, we landed in melbourne.
src_text: after three months in a refugee camp, we landed in melbourne.

tgt_text: and the next piece of the jigsaw is about four women across three generations shaping a new life together.
src_text: and the next piece of the jigsaw is about four women across three generations shaping a new life together.

tgt_text: we settled in footscray, a working-class suburb whose demographic is layers of immigrants.
src_text: we settled in footscray, a working-class suburb whose demographic is layers of immigrants.

tgt_text: unlike the settled middle-class suburbs, whose existence i was oblivious of, there was no sense of entitlement in footscray.
src_text: unlike the settled middle-class suburbs, whose existence i was oblivious of, there was no sense of entitlement in footscray.

tgt_text: the smells from shop doors were from the rest of the world.
src_text: the smells from shop doors were from the rest of the world.

tgt_text: and the snippets of halting english were exchanged between people who had one thing in common: they were starting again.
src_text: and the snippets of halting english were exchanged between people who had one thing in common: they were starting again.

tgt_text: my mother worked on farms, then on a car assembly line, working six days, double shifts.
src_text: my mother worked on farms, then on a car assembly line, working six days, double shifts.

tgt_text: somehow, she found time to study english and gain it qualifications. we were poor. all the dollars were allocated and extra tuition in english and mathematics was budgeted for regardless of what missed out, which was usually new clothes; they were always secondhand.
src_text: somehow, she found time to study english and gain it qualifications. we were poor. all the dollars were allocated and extra tuition in english and mathematics was budgeted for regardless of what missed out, which was usually new clothes; they were always secondhand.

tgt_text: two pairs of stockings for school, each to hide the holes in the other.
src_text: two pairs of stockings for school, each to hide the holes in the other.

tgt_text: a school uniform down to the ankles, because it had to last for six years.
src_text: a school uniform down to the ankles, because it had to last for six years.

tgt_text: and there were rare but searing chants of "slit-eye" and the occasional graffiti: "asian, go home." go home to where?
src_text: and there were rare but searing chants of "slit-eye" and the occasional graffiti: "asian, go home." go home to where?

tgt_text: something stiffened inside me.
src_text: something stiffened inside me.

tgt_text: there was a gathering of resolve and a quiet voice saying, "i will bypass you."
src_text: there was a gathering of resolve and a quiet voice saying, "i will bypass you."

tgt_text: my mother, my sister and i slept in the same bed.
src_text: my mother, my sister and i slept in the same bed.

tgt_text: my mother was exhausted each night, but we told one another about our day and listened to the movements of my grandmother around the house.
src_text: my mother was exhausted each night, but we told one another about our day and listened to the movements of my grandmother around the house.

tgt_text: my mother suffered from nightmares, all about the boat.
src_text: my mother suffered from nightmares, all about the boat.

tgt_text: and my job was to stay awake until her nightmares came so i could wake her.
src_text: and my job was to stay awake until her nightmares came so i could wake her.

tgt_text: she opened a computer store, then studied to be a beautician and opened another business.
src_text: she opened a computer store, then studied to be a beautician and opened another business.

tgt_text: and the women came with their stories about men who could not make the transition, angry and inflexible, and troubled children caught between two worlds.
src_text: and the women came with their stories about men who could not make the transition, angry and inflexible, and troubled children caught between two worlds.

tgt_text: grants and sponsors were sought. centers were established. i lived in parallel worlds.
src_text: grants and sponsors were sought. centers were established. i lived in parallel worlds.

tgt_text: in one, i was the classic asian student, relentless in the demands that i made on myself.
src_text: in one, i was the classic asian student, relentless in the demands that i made on myself.

tgt_text: in the other, i was enmeshed in lives that were precarious, tragically scarred by violence, drug abuse and isolation.
src_text: in the other, i was enmeshed in lives that were precarious, tragically scarred by violence, drug abuse and isolation.

tgt_text: but so many over the years were helped.
src_text: but so many over the years were helped.

tgt_text: and for that work, when i was a final-year law student, i was chosen as the young australian of the year.
src_text: and for that work, when i was a final-year law student, i was chosen as the young australian of the year.

tgt_text: and i was catapulted from one piece of the jigsaw to another, and their edges didn't fit.
src_text: and i was catapulted from one piece of the jigsaw to another, and their edges didn't fit.

tgt_text: tan le, anonymous footscray resident, was now tan le, refugee and social activist, invited to speak in venues she had never heard of and into homes whose existence she could never have imagined.
src_text: tan le, anonymous footscray resident, was now tan le, refugee and social activist, invited to speak in venues she had never heard of and into homes whose existence she could never have imagined.

tgt_text: i didn't know the protocols.
src_text: i didn't know the protocols.

tgt_text: i didn't know how to use the cutlery.
src_text: i didn't know how to use the cutlery.

tgt_text: i didn't know how to talk about wine.
src_text: i didn't know how to talk about wine.

tgt_text: i didn't know how to talk about anything.
src_text: i didn't know how to talk about anything.

tgt_text: i wanted to retreat to the routines and comfort of life in an unsung suburb — a grandmother, a mother and two daughters ending each day as they had for almost 20 years, telling one another the story of their day and falling asleep, the three of us still in the same bed.
src_text: i wanted to retreat to the routines and comfort of life in an unsung suburb — a grandmother, a mother and two daughters ending each day as they had for almost 20 years, telling one another the story of their day and falling asleep, the three of us still in the same bed.

tgt_text: i told my mother i couldn't do it.
src_text: i told my mother i couldn't do it.

tgt_text: she reminded me that i was now the same age she had been when we boarded the boat. "no" had never been an option. "just do it," she said, "and don't be what you're not."
src_text: she reminded me that i was now the same age she had been when we boarded the boat. "no" had never been an option. "just do it," she said, "and don't be what you're not."

tgt_text: so i spoke out on youth unemployment and education and the neglect of the marginalized and disenfranchised.
src_text: so i spoke out on youth unemployment and education and the neglect of the marginalized and disenfranchised.

tgt_text: and the more candidly i spoke, the more i was asked to speak.
src_text: and the more candidly i spoke, the more i was asked to speak.

tgt_text: i met people from all walks of life, so many of them doing the thing they loved, living on the frontiers of possibility.
src_text: i met people from all walks of life, so many of them doing the thing they loved, living on the frontiers of possibility.

tgt_text: and even though i finished my degree, i realized i could not settle into a career in law.
src_text: and even though i finished my degree, i realized i could not settle into a career in law.

tgt_text: there had to be another piece of the jigsaw.
src_text: there had to be another piece of the jigsaw.

tgt_text: and i realized, at the same time, that it is ok to be an outsider, a recent arrival, new on the scene — and not just ok, but something to be thankful for, perhaps a gift from the boat.
src_text: and i realized, at the same time, that it is ok to be an outsider, a recent arrival, new on the scene — and not just ok, but something to be thankful for, perhaps a gift from the boat.

tgt_text: because being an insider can so easily mean collapsing the horizons, can so easily mean accepting the presumptions of your province.
src_text: because being an insider can so easily mean collapsing the horizons, can so easily mean accepting the presumptions of your province.

tgt_text: i have stepped outside my comfort zone enough now to know that, yes, the world does fall apart, but not in the way that you fear.
src_text: i have stepped outside my comfort zone enough now to know that, yes, the world does fall apart, but not in the way that you fear.

tgt_text: possibilities that would not have been allowed were outrageously encouraged.
src_text: possibilities that would not have been allowed were outrageously encouraged.

tgt_text: there was an energy there, an implacable optimism, a strange mixture of humility and daring.
src_text: there was an energy there, an implacable optimism, a strange mixture of humility and daring.

tgt_text: so i followed my hunches.
src_text: so i followed my hunches.

tgt_text: i gathered around me a small team of people for whom the label "it can't be done" was an irresistible challenge.
src_text: i gathered around me a small team of people for whom the label "it can't be done" was an irresistible challenge.

tgt_text: for a year, we were penniless.
src_text: for a year, we were penniless.

tgt_text: at the end of each day, i made a huge pot of soup which we all shared.
src_text: at the end of each day, i made a huge pot of soup which we all shared.

tgt_text: we worked well into each night.
src_text: we worked well into each night.

tgt_text: most of our ideas were crazy, but a few were brilliant, and we broke through.
src_text: most of our ideas were crazy, but a few were brilliant, and we broke through.

tgt_text: i made the decision to move to the us after only one trip. my hunches again. three months later, i had relocated, and the adventure has continued.
src_text: i made the decision to move to the us after only one trip. my hunches again. three months later, i had relocated, and the adventure has continued.

tgt_text: before i close, though, let me tell you about my grandmother.
src_text: before i close, though, let me tell you about my grandmother.

tgt_text: she grew up at a time when confucianism was the social norm and the local mandarin was the person who mattered.
src_text: she grew up at a time when confucianism was the social norm and the local mandarin was the person who mattered.

tgt_text: life hadn't changed for centuries.
src_text: life hadn't changed for centuries.

tgt_text: her father died soon after she was born.
src_text: her father died soon after she was born.

tgt_text: her mother raised her alone.
src_text: her mother raised her alone.

tgt_text: at 17, she became the second wife of a mandarin whose mother beat her.
src_text: at 17, she became the second wife of a mandarin whose mother beat her.

tgt_text: with no support from her husband, she caused a sensation by taking him to court and prosecuting her own case, and a far greater sensation when she won. (laughter) (applause) "it can't be done" was shown to be wrong.
src_text: with no support from her husband, she caused a sensation by taking him to court and prosecuting her own case, and a far greater sensation when she won. (laughter) (applause) "it can't be done" was shown to be wrong.

tgt_text: i was taking a shower in a hotel room in sydney the moment she died, 600 miles away, in melbourne.
src_text: i was taking a shower in a hotel room in sydney the moment she died, 600 miles away, in melbourne.

tgt_text: i looked through the shower screen and saw her standing on the other side.
src_text: i looked through the shower screen and saw her standing on the other side.

tgt_text: i knew she had come to say goodbye.
src_text: i knew she had come to say goodbye.

tgt_text: my mother phoned minutes later.
src_text: my mother phoned minutes later.

tgt_text: a few days later, we went to a buddhist temple in footscray and sat around her casket.
src_text: a few days later, we went to a buddhist temple in footscray and sat around her casket.

tgt_text: we told her stories and assured her that we were still with her.
src_text: we told her stories and assured her that we were still with her.

tgt_text: at midnight, the monk came and told us he had to close the casket.
src_text: at midnight, the monk came and told us he had to close the casket.

tgt_text: my mother asked us to feel her hand.
src_text: my mother asked us to feel her hand.

tgt_text: she asked the monk, "why is it that her hand is so warm and the rest of her is so cold?" "because you have been holding it since this morning," he said. "you have not let it go."
src_text: she asked the monk, "why is it that her hand is so warm and the rest of her is so cold?" "because you have been holding it since this morning," he said. "you have not let it go."

tgt_text: if there is a sinew in our family, it runs through the women.
src_text: if there is a sinew in our family, it runs through the women.

tgt_text: given who we were and how life had shaped us, we can now see that the men that might have come into our lives would have thwarted us.
src_text: given who we were and how life had shaped us, we can now see that the men that might have come into our lives would have thwarted us.

tgt_text: defeat would have come too easily.
src_text: defeat would have come too easily.

tgt_text: now i would like to have my own children, and i wonder about the boat.
src_text: now i would like to have my own children, and i wonder about the boat.

tgt_text: who could ever wish it on their own?
src_text: who could ever wish it on their own?

tgt_text: yet i am afraid of privilege, of ease, of entitlement.
src_text: yet i am afraid of privilege, of ease, of entitlement.

tgt_text: can i give them a bow in their lives, dipping bravely into each wave, the unperturbed and steady beat of the engine, the vast horizon that guarantees nothing?
src_text: can i give them a bow in their lives, dipping bravely into each wave, the unperturbed and steady beat of the engine, the vast horizon that guarantees nothing?

tgt_text: i don't know.
src_text: i don't know.

tgt_text: but if i could give it and still see them safely through, i would.
src_text: but if i could give it and still see them safely through, i would.

tgt_text: (applause)
src_text: (applause)

tgt_text: trevor neilson: and also, tan's mother is here today, in the fourth or fifth row.
src_text: trevor neilson: and also, tan's mother is here today, in the fourth or fifth row.

tgt_text: hi. i'm kevin allocca, i'm the trends manager at youtube, and i professionally watch youtube videos. it's true. so we're going to talk a little bit today about how videos go viral and then why that even matters.
src_text: hi. i'm kevin allocca, i'm the trends manager at youtube, and i professionally watch youtube videos. it's true. so we're going to talk a little bit today about how videos go viral and then why that even matters.

tgt_text: we all want to be stars — celebrities, singers, comedians — and when i was younger, that seemed so very, very hard to do.
src_text: we all want to be stars — celebrities, singers, comedians — and when i was younger, that seemed so very, very hard to do.

tgt_text: but now web video has made it so that any of us or any of the creative things that we do can become completely famous in a part of our world's culture.
src_text: but now web video has made it so that any of us or any of the creative things that we do can become completely famous in a part of our world's culture.

tgt_text: any one of you could be famous on the internet by next saturday.
src_text: any one of you could be famous on the internet by next saturday.

tgt_text: but there are over 48 hours of video uploaded to youtube every minute.
src_text: but there are over 48 hours of video uploaded to youtube every minute.

tgt_text: and of that, only a tiny percentage ever goes viral and gets tons of views and becomes a cultural moment.
src_text: and of that, only a tiny percentage ever goes viral and gets tons of views and becomes a cultural moment.

tgt_text: so how does it happen?
src_text: so how does it happen?

tgt_text: three things: tastemakers, communities of participation and unexpectedness.
src_text: three things: tastemakers, communities of participation and unexpectedness.

tgt_text: all right, let's go.
src_text: all right, let's go.

src_text: (video) bear vasquez: oh, my god. oh, my god. oh, my god! wooo! ohhhhh, wowwww!

src_text: but he didn't actually set out to make a viral video, bear.

src_text: so what happened here? jimmy kimmel actually. jimmy kimmel posted this tweet that would eventually propel the video to be as popular as it would become.

tgt_text: because tastemakers like jimmy kimmel introduce us to new and interesting things and bring them to a larger audience.

tgt_text: the point is that the news media preferentially feeds us negative stories because that's what our minds pay attention to.
src_text: the point is that the news media preferentially feeds us negative stories because that's what our minds pay attention to.

tgt_text: and there's a very good reason for that.
src_text: and there's a very good reason for that.

tgt_text: every second of every day, our senses bring in way too much data than we can possibly process in our brains.
src_text: every second of every day, our senses bring in way too much data than we can possibly process in our brains.

tgt_text: and because nothing is more important to us than survival, the first stop of all of that data is an ancient sliver of the temporal lobe called the amygdala.
src_text: and because nothing is more important to us than survival, the first stop of all of that data is an ancient sliver of the temporal lobe called the amygdala.

tgt_text: now the amygdala is our early warning detector, our danger detector.
src_text: now the amygdala is our early warning detector, our danger detector.

tgt_text: it sorts and scours through all of the information looking for anything in the environment that might harm us.
src_text: it sorts and scours through all of the information looking for anything in the environment that might harm us.

tgt_text: so given a dozen news stories, we will preferentially look at the negative news.
src_text: so given a dozen news stories, we will preferentially look at the negative news.

tgt_text: and that old newspaper saying, "if it bleeds it leads," is very true.
src_text: and that old newspaper saying, "if it bleeds it leads," is very true.

tgt_text: so given all of our digital devices that are bringing all the negative news to us seven days a week, 24 hours a day, it's no wonder that we're pessimistic.
src_text: so given all of our digital devices that are bringing all the negative news to us seven days a week, 24 hours a day, it's no wonder that we're pessimistic.

tgt_text: it's no wonder that people think that the world is getting worse.
src_text: it's no wonder that people think that the world is getting worse.

tgt_text: but perhaps that's not the case.
src_text: but perhaps that's not the case.

tgt_text: perhaps instead, it's the distortions brought to us of what's really going on.
src_text: perhaps instead, it's the distortions brought to us of what's really going on.

tgt_text: perhaps the tremendous progress we've made over the last century by a series of forces are, in fact, accelerating to a point that we have the potential in the next three decades to create a world of abundance.
src_text: perhaps the tremendous progress we've made over the last century by a series of forces are, in fact, accelerating to a point that we have the potential in the next three decades to create a world of abundance.

tgt_text: now i'm not saying we don't have our set of problems — climate crisis, species extinction, water and energy shortage — we surely do.
src_text: now i'm not saying we don't have our set of problems — climate crisis, species extinction, water and energy shortage — we surely do.

tgt_text: and as humans, we are far better at seeing the problems way in advance, but ultimately we knock them down.
src_text: and as humans, we are far better at seeing the problems way in advance, but ultimately we knock them down.

tgt_text: so let's look at what this last century has been to see where we're going.
src_text: so let's look at what this last century has been to see where we're going.

tgt_text: over the last hundred years, the average human lifespan has more than doubled, average per capita income adjusted for inflation around the world has tripled.
src_text: over the last hundred years, the average human lifespan has more than doubled, average per capita income adjusted for inflation around the world has tripled.

tgt_text: childhood mortality has come down a factor of 10.
src_text: childhood mortality has come down a factor of 10.

tgt_text: add to that the cost of food, electricity, transportation, communication have dropped 10 to 1,000-fold.
src_text: add to that the cost of food, electricity, transportation, communication have dropped 10 to 1,000-fold.

tgt_text: steve pinker has showed us that, in fact, we're living during the most peaceful time ever in human history.
src_text: steve pinker has showed us that, in fact, we're living during the most peaceful time ever in human history.

tgt_text: and charles kenny that global literacy has gone from 25 percent to over 80 percent in the last 130 years.
src_text: and charles kenny that global literacy has gone from 25 percent to over 80 percent in the last 130 years.

tgt_text: we truly are living in an extraordinary time.
src_text: we truly are living in an extraordinary time.

tgt_text: and many people forget this.
src_text: and many people forget this.

tgt_text: and we keep setting our expectations higher and higher.
src_text: and we keep setting our expectations higher and higher.

tgt_text: in fact, we redefine what poverty means.
src_text: in fact, we redefine what poverty means.

tgt_text: think of this, in america today, the majority of people under the poverty line still have electricity, water, toilets, refrigerators, television, mobile phones, air conditioning and cars.
src_text: think of this, in america today, the majority of people under the poverty line still have electricity, water, toilets, refrigerators, television, mobile phones, air conditioning and cars.

tgt_text: the wealthiest robber barons of the last century, the emperors on this planet, could have never dreamed of such luxuries.
src_text: the wealthiest robber barons of the last century, the emperors on this planet, could have never dreamed of such luxuries.

tgt_text: underpinning much of this is technology, and of late, exponentially growing technologies.
src_text: underpinning much of this is technology, and of late, exponentially growing technologies.

tgt_text: my good friend ray kurzweil showed that any tool that becomes an information technology jumps on this curve, on moore's law, and experiences price performance doubling every 12 to 24 months.
src_text: my good friend ray kurzweil showed that any tool that becomes an information technology jumps on this curve, on moore's law, and experiences price performance doubling every 12 to 24 months.

tgt_text: that's why the cellphone in your pocket is literally a million times cheaper and a thousand times faster than a supercomputer of the '70s.
src_text: that's why the cellphone in your pocket is literally a million times cheaper and a thousand times faster than a supercomputer of the '70s.

tgt_text: now look at this curve.

tgt_text: this is moore's law over the last hundred years.
src_text: this is moore's law over the last hundred years.

tgt_text: i want you to notice two things from this curve.
src_text: i want you to notice two things from this curve.

tgt_text: number one, how smooth it is — through good time and bad time, war time and peace time, recession, depression and boom time.
src_text: number one, how smooth it is — through good time and bad time, war time and peace time, recession, depression and boom time.

tgt_text: this is the result of faster computers being used to build faster computers.
src_text: this is the result of faster computers being used to build faster computers.

tgt_text: it doesn't slow for any of our grand challenges.
src_text: it doesn't slow for any of our grand challenges.

tgt_text: and also, even though it's plotted on a log curve on the left, it's curving upwards.
src_text: and also, even though it's plotted on a log curve on the left, it's curving upwards.

tgt_text: the rate at which the technology is getting faster is itself getting faster.
src_text: the rate at which the technology is getting faster is itself getting faster.

tgt_text: and we teach our students all of these technologies, and particularly how they can be used to solve humanity's grand challenges.

tgt_text: and every year we ask them to start a company or a product or a service that can affect positively the lives of a billion people within a decade.

tgt_text: when i think about creating abundance, it's not about creating a life of luxury for everybody on this planet; it's about creating a life of possibility.

tgt_text: it is about taking that which was scarce and making it abundant.

tgt_text: you see, scarcity is contextual, and technology is a resource-liberating force.

tgt_text: so this is a story of napoleon iii in the mid-1800s.

tgt_text: it's all bound by oxygen and silicates.

tgt_text: and yet, in this country, in the states of the old south, we execute people — where you're 11 times more likely to get the death penalty if the victim is white than if the victim is black, 22 times more likely to get it if the defendant is black and the victim is white — in the very states where there are buried in the ground the bodies of people who were lynched.
