tgt_text: so a couple of years ago i started a program to try to get the rockstar tech and design people to take a year off and work in the one environment that represents pretty much everything they're supposed to hate; we have them work in government.
src_text: so a couple of years ago i started a program to try to get the rockstar tech and design people to take a year off and work in the one environment that represents pretty much everything they're supposed to hate; we have them work in government.

tgt_text: the program is called code for america, and it's a little bit like a peace corps for geeks.
src_text: the program is called code for america, and it's a little bit like a peace corps for geeks.

tgt_text: we select a few fellows every year and we have them work with city governments.
src_text: we select a few fellows every year and we have them work with city governments.

tgt_text: instead of sending them off into the third world, we send them into the wilds of city hall.
src_text: instead of sending them off into the third world, we send them into the wilds of city hall.

tgt_text: and there they make great apps, they work with city staffers.
src_text: and there they make great apps, they work with city staffers.

tgt_text: but really what they're doing is they're showing what's possible with technology today.

tgt_text: so meet al. al is a fire hydrant in the city of boston.
src_text: so meet al. al is a fire hydrant in the city of boston.

tgt_text: here it kind of looks like he's looking for a date, but what he's really looking for is for someone to shovel him out when he gets snowed in, because he knows he's not very good at fighting fires when he's covered in four feet of snow.
src_text: here it kind of looks like he's looking for a date, but what he's really looking for is for someone to shovel him out when he gets snowed in, because he knows he's not very good at fighting fires when he's covered in four feet of snow.

tgt_text: now how did he come to be looking for help in this very unique manner?
src_text: now how did he come to be looking for help in this very unique manner?

tgt_text: we had a team of fellows in boston last year through the code for america program.
src_text: we had a team of fellows in boston last year through the code for america program.

tgt_text: they were there in february, and it snowed a lot in february last year.
src_text: they were there in february, and it snowed a lot in february last year.

tgt_text: and they noticed that the city never gets to digging out these fire hydrants.

src_text: but one fellow in particular, a guy named erik michaels-ober, noticed something else, and that's that citizens are shoveling out sidewalks right in front of these things.

tgt_text: so he did what any good developer would do, he wrote an app.
src_text: so he did what any good developer would do, he wrote an app.

tgt_text: it's a cute little app where you can adopt a fire hydrant.
src_text: it's a cute little app where you can adopt a fire hydrant.

tgt_text: so you agree to dig it out when it snows.
src_text: so you agree to dig it out when it snows.

tgt_text: if you do, you get to name it, and he called the first one al.

tgt_text: so it's got cute little game dynamics on it.

tgt_text: this is a modest little app.

tgt_text: it's probably the smallest of the 21 apps that the fellows wrote last year.
src_text: it's probably the smallest of the 21 apps that the fellows wrote last year.

tgt_text: but it's doing something that no other government technology does.

tgt_text: it's spreading virally.
src_text: it's spreading virally.

tgt_text: there's a guy in the i.t. department of the city of honolulu who saw this app and realized that he could use it, not for snow, but to get citizens to adopt tsunami sirens.

tgt_text: it's very important that these tsunami sirens work, but people steal the batteries out of them.

tgt_text: so we now know of nine cities that are planning to use this.

tgt_text: and this has spread just frictionlessly, organically, naturally.
src_text: and this has spread just frictionlessly, organically, naturally.

tgt_text: if you know anything about government technology, you know that this isn't how it normally goes.
src_text: if you know anything about government technology, you know that this isn't how it normally goes.

tgt_text: procuring software usually takes a couple of years.
src_text: procuring software usually takes a couple of years.

tgt_text: we had a team that worked on a project in boston last year that took three people about two and a half months.
src_text: we had a team that worked on a project in boston last year that took three people about two and a half months.

tgt_text: it was a way that parents could figure out which were the right public schools for their kids.

tgt_text: we were told afterward that if that had gone through normal channels, it would have taken at least two years and it would have cost about two million dollars.

tgt_text: and that's nothing.
src_text: and that's nothing.

tgt_text: there is one project in the california court system right now that so far cost taxpayers two billion dollars, and it doesn't work.

tgt_text: and there are projects like this at every level of government.

tgt_text: so an app that takes a couple of days to write and then spreads virally, that's sort of a shot across the bow to the institution of government.
src_text: so an app that takes a couple of days to write and then spreads virally, that's sort of a shot across the bow to the institution of government.

tgt_text: it suggests how government could work better — not more like a private company, as many people think it should.
src_text: it suggests how government could work better — not more like a private company, as many people think it should.

tgt_text: and not even like a tech company, but more like the internet itself.
src_text: and not even like a tech company, but more like the internet itself.

tgt_text: and that means permissionless, it means open, it means generative.
src_text: and that means permissionless, it means open, it means generative.

tgt_text: and that's important.
src_text: and that's important.

tgt_text: but what's more important about this app is that it represents how a new generation is tackling the problem of government — not as the problem of an ossified institution, but as a problem of collective action.
src_text: but what's more important about this app is that it represents how a new generation is tackling the problem of government — not as the problem of an ossified institution, but as a problem of collective action.

tgt_text: and that's great news, because, it turns out, we're very good at collective action with digital technology.
src_text: and that's great news, because, it turns out, we're very good at collective action with digital technology.

tgt_text: now there's a very large community of people that are building the tools that we need to do things together effectively.

tgt_text: it's not just code for america fellows, there are hundreds of people all over the country that are standing and writing civic apps every day in their own communities.

tgt_text: they haven't given up on government.
src_text: they haven't given up on government.

tgt_text: they are frustrated as hell with it, but they're not complaining about it, they're fixing it.
src_text: they are frustrated as hell with it, but they're not complaining about it, they're fixing it.

tgt_text: and these folks know something that we've lost sight of.
src_text: and these folks know something that we've lost sight of.

tgt_text: and that's that when you strip away all your feelings about politics and the line at the dmv and all those other things that we're really mad about, government is, at its core, in the words of tim o'reilly, "what we do together that we can't do alone."
src_text: and that's that when you strip away all your feelings about politics and the line at the dmv and all those other things that we're really mad about, government is, at its core, in the words of tim o'reilly, "what we do together that we can't do alone."

tgt_text: now a lot of people have given up on government.

tgt_text: and if you're one of those people, i would ask that you reconsider, because things are changing.
src_text: and if you're one of those people, i would ask that you reconsider, because things are changing.

tgt_text: politics is not changing; government is changing.
src_text: politics is not changing; government is changing.

tgt_text: and because government ultimately derives its power from us — remember "we the people?" — how we think about it is going to effect how that change happens.
src_text: and because government ultimately derives its power from us — remember "we the people?" — how we think about it is going to effect how that change happens.

tgt_text: now i didn't know very much about government when i started this program.
src_text: now i didn't know very much about government when i started this program.

tgt_text: and like a lot of people, i thought government was basically about getting people elected to office.
src_text: and like a lot of people, i thought government was basically about getting people elected to office.

tgt_text: well after two years, i've come to the conclusion that, especially local government, is about opossums.
src_text: well after two years, i've come to the conclusion that, especially local government, is about opossums.

tgt_text: this is the call center for the services and information line.
src_text: this is the call center for the services and information line.

tgt_text: it's generally where you will get if you call 311 in your city.
src_text: it's generally where you will get if you call 311 in your city.

tgt_text: if you should ever have the chance to staff your city's call center, as our fellow scott silverman did as part of the program — in fact, they all do that — you will find that people call government with a very wide range of issues, including having an opossum stuck in your house.

tgt_text: pretty simple. so this is great. this is the digital meeting the physical.

tgt_text: now one of the important things we need to think about government is that it's not the same thing as politics.
src_text: now one of the important things we need to think about government is that it's not the same thing as politics.

tgt_text: and most people get that, but they think that one is the input to the other.

tgt_text: that our input to the system of government is voting.

tgt_text: now how many times have we elected a political leader — and sometimes we spend a lot of energy getting a new political leader elected — and then we sit back and we expect government to reflect our values and meet our needs, and then not that much changes?
src_text: now how many times have we elected a political leader — and sometimes we spend a lot of energy getting a new political leader elected — and then we sit back and we expect government to reflect our values and meet our needs, and then not that much changes?

tgt_text: that's because government is like a vast ocean and politics is the six-inch layer on top.

tgt_text: and what's under that is what we call bureaucracy.

tgt_text: and we say that word with such contempt.

tgt_text: but it's that contempt that keeps this thing that we own and we pay for as something that's working against us, this other thing, and then we're disempowering ourselves.
src_text: but it's that contempt that keeps this thing that we own and we pay for as something that's working against us, this other thing, and then we're disempowering ourselves.

tgt_text: people seem to think politics is sexy.

tgt_text: that's not being politically active, that's being bureaucratically active.

tgt_text: now for those of us who've given up on government, it's time that we asked ourselves about the world that we want to leave for our children.
src_text: now for those of us who've given up on government, it's time that we asked ourselves about the world that we want to leave for our children.

tgt_text: you have to see the enormous challenges that they're going to face.
src_text: you have to see the enormous challenges that they're going to face.

tgt_text: do we really think we're going to get where we need to go without fixing the one institution that can act on behalf of all of us?
src_text: do we really think we're going to get where we need to go without fixing the one institution that can act on behalf of all of us?

tgt_text: we can't do without government, but we do need it to be more effective.
src_text: we can't do without government, but we do need it to be more effective.

tgt_text: the good news is that technology is making it possible to fundamentally reframe the function of government in a way that can actually scale by strengthening civil society.
src_text: the good news is that technology is making it possible to fundamentally reframe the function of government in a way that can actually scale by strengthening civil society.

tgt_text: and there's a generation out there that's grown up on the internet, and they know that it's not that hard to do things together, you just have to architect the systems the right way.
src_text: and there's a generation out there that's grown up on the internet, and they know that it's not that hard to do things together, you just have to architect the systems the right way.

tgt_text: now the average age of our fellows is 28, so i am, begrudgingly, almost a generation older than most of them.
src_text: now the average age of our fellows is 28, so i am, begrudgingly, almost a generation older than most of them.

tgt_text: this is a generation that's grown up taking their voices pretty much for granted.
src_text: this is a generation that's grown up taking their voices pretty much for granted.

tgt_text: they're not fighting that battle that we're all fighting about who gets to speak; they all get to speak.
src_text: they're not fighting that battle that we're all fighting about who gets to speak; they all get to speak.

tgt_text: they can express their opinion on any channel at any time, and they do.
src_text: they can express their opinion on any channel at any time, and they do.

tgt_text: so when they're faced with the problem of government, they don't care as much about using their voices.
src_text: so when they're faced with the problem of government, they don't care as much about using their voices.

tgt_text: they're using their hands.
src_text: they're using their hands.

tgt_text: they're using their hands to write applications that make government work better.
src_text: they're using their hands to write applications that make government work better.

tgt_text: and those applications let us use our hands to make our communities better.
src_text: and those applications let us use our hands to make our communities better.

tgt_text: that could be shoveling out a hydrant, pulling a weed, turning over a garbage can with an opossum in it.
src_text: that could be shoveling out a hydrant, pulling a weed, turning over a garbage can with an opossum in it.

tgt_text: and certainly, we could have been shoveling out those fire hydrants all along, and many people do.
src_text: and certainly, we could have been shoveling out those fire hydrants all along, and many people do.

tgt_text: but these apps are like little digital reminders that we're not just consumers, and we're not just consumers of government, putting in our taxes and getting back services.
src_text: but these apps are like little digital reminders that we're not just consumers, and we're not just consumers of government, putting in our taxes and getting back services.

tgt_text: we're more than that, we're citizens.
src_text: we're more than that, we're citizens.

tgt_text: and we're not going to fix government until we fix citizenship.
src_text: and we're not going to fix government until we fix citizenship.

tgt_text: so the question i have for all of you here: when it comes to the big, important things that we need to do together, all of us together, are we just going to be a crowd of voices, or are we also going to be a crowd of hands?
src_text: so the question i have for all of you here: when it comes to the big, important things that we need to do together, all of us together, are we just going to be a crowd of voices, or are we also going to be a crowd of hands?

tgt_text: thank you.
src_text: thank you.

src_text: (applause)

tgt_text: this may sound strange, but i'm a big fan of the concrete block.
src_text: this may sound strange, but i'm a big fan of the concrete block.

tgt_text: the first concrete blocks were manufactured in 1868 with a very simple idea: modules made of cement of a fixed measurement that fit together.
src_text: the first concrete blocks were manufactured in 1868 with a very simple idea: modules made of cement of a fixed measurement that fit together.

tgt_text: very quickly concrete blocks became the most-used construction unit in the world.
src_text: very quickly concrete blocks became the most-used construction unit in the world.

tgt_text: they enabled us to to build things that were larger than us, buildings, bridges, one brick at a time.
src_text: they enabled us to to build things that were larger than us, buildings, bridges, one brick at a time.

tgt_text: essentially concrete blocks had become the building block of our time.
src_text: essentially concrete blocks had become the building block of our time.

tgt_text: almost a hundred years later in 1947, lego came up with this.
src_text: almost a hundred years later in 1947, lego came up with this.

tgt_text: it was called the automatic binding brick.
src_text: it was called the automatic binding brick.

tgt_text: and in a few short years, lego bricks took place in every household.
src_text: and in a few short years, lego bricks took place in every household.

tgt_text: it's estimated that over 400 billion bricks have been produced — or 75 bricks for every person on the planet.
src_text: it's estimated that over 400 billion bricks have been produced — or 75 bricks for every person on the planet.

tgt_text: you don't have to be an engineer to make beautiful houses, beautiful bridges, beautiful buildings.
src_text: you don't have to be an engineer to make beautiful houses, beautiful bridges, beautiful buildings.

tgt_text: lego made it accessible.
src_text: lego made it accessible.

tgt_text: lego has essentially taken the concrete block, the building block of the world, and made it into the building block of our imagination.
src_text: lego has essentially taken the concrete block, the building block of the world, and made it into the building block of our imagination.

tgt_text: meanwhile the exact same year, at bell labs the next revolution was about to be announced, the next building block.
src_text: meanwhile the exact same year, at bell labs the next revolution was about to be announced, the next building block.

tgt_text: the transistor was a small plastic unit that would take us from a world of static bricks piled on top of each other to a world where everything was interactive.
src_text: the transistor was a small plastic unit that would take us from a world of static bricks piled on top of each other to a world where everything was interactive.

tgt_text: like the concrete block, the transistor allows you to build much larger, more complex circuits, one brick at a time.
src_text: like the concrete block, the transistor allows you to build much larger, more complex circuits, one brick at a time.

tgt_text: but there's a main difference: the transistor was only for experts.
src_text: but there's a main difference: the transistor was only for experts.

tgt_text: i personally don't accept this, that the building block of our time is reserved for experts, so i decided to change that.
src_text: i personally don't accept this, that the building block of our time is reserved for experts, so i decided to change that.

tgt_text: eight years ago when i was at the media lab, i started exploring this idea of how to put the power of engineers in the hands of artists and designers.
src_text: eight years ago when i was at the media lab, i started exploring this idea of how to put the power of engineers in the hands of artists and designers.

tgt_text: a few years ago i started developing littlebits.
src_text: a few years ago i started developing littlebits.

tgt_text: let me show you how they work.
src_text: let me show you how they work.

tgt_text: littlebits are electronic modules with each one specific function.
src_text: littlebits are electronic modules with each one specific function.

tgt_text: they're pre-engineered to be light, sound, motors and sensors.
src_text: they're pre-engineered to be light, sound, motors and sensors.

tgt_text: and the best part about it is they snap together with magnets.
src_text: and the best part about it is they snap together with magnets.

tgt_text: so you can't put them the wrong way.
src_text: so you can't put them the wrong way.

tgt_text: the bricks are color-coded.
src_text: the bricks are color-coded.

tgt_text: green is output, blue is power, pink is input and orange is wire.
src_text: green is output, blue is power, pink is input and orange is wire.

tgt_text: so all you need to do is snap a blue to a green and very quickly you can start making larger circuits.
src_text: so all you need to do is snap a blue to a green and very quickly you can start making larger circuits.

tgt_text: you put a blue to a green, you can make light.
src_text: you put a blue to a green, you can make light.

tgt_text: you can put a knob in between and now you've made a little dimmer.
src_text: you can put a knob in between and now you've made a little dimmer.

tgt_text: switch out the knob for a pulse module, which is here, and now you've made a little blinker.
src_text: switch out the knob for a pulse module, which is here, and now you've made a little blinker.

tgt_text: add this buzzer for some extra punch and you've created a noise machine.
src_text: add this buzzer for some extra punch and you've created a noise machine.

tgt_text: i'm going to stop that.
src_text: i'm going to stop that.

tgt_text: so beyond simple play, littlebits are actually pretty powerful.
src_text: so beyond simple play, littlebits are actually pretty powerful.

tgt_text: instead of having to program, to wire, to solder, littlebits allow you to program using very simple intuitive gestures.
src_text: instead of having to program, to wire, to solder, littlebits allow you to program using very simple intuitive gestures.

tgt_text: so to make this blink faster or slower, you would just turn this knob and basically make it pulse faster or slower.
src_text: so to make this blink faster or slower, you would just turn this knob and basically make it pulse faster or slower.

tgt_text: the idea behind littlebits is that it's a growing library.
src_text: the idea behind littlebits is that it's a growing library.

tgt_text: we want to make every single interaction in the world into a ready-to-use brick.
src_text: we want to make every single interaction in the world into a ready-to-use brick.

tgt_text: lights, sounds, solar panels, motors — everything should be accessible.
src_text: lights, sounds, solar panels, motors — everything should be accessible.

tgt_text: we've been giving littlebits to kids and seeing them play with them.
src_text: we've been giving littlebits to kids and seeing them play with them.

tgt_text: and it's been an incredible experience.
src_text: and it's been an incredible experience.

tgt_text: the nicest thing is how they start to understand the electronics around them from everyday that they don't learn at schools.
src_text: the nicest thing is how they start to understand the electronics around them from everyday that they don't learn at schools.

tgt_text: for example, how a nightlight works, or why an elevator door stays open, or how an ipod responds to touch.
src_text: for example, how a nightlight works, or why an elevator door stays open, or how an ipod responds to touch.

tgt_text: we've also been taking littlebits to design schools.
src_text: we've also been taking littlebits to design schools.

tgt_text: so for example, we've had designers with no experience with electronics whatsoever start to play with littlebits as a material.
src_text: so for example, we've had designers with no experience with electronics whatsoever start to play with littlebits as a material.

tgt_text: here you see, with felt and paper water bottles, we have geordie making...
src_text: here you see, with felt and paper water bottles, we have geordie making...

tgt_text: a few weeks ago we took littlebits to risd and gave them to some designers with no experience in engineering whatsoever — just cardboard, wood and paper — and told them "make something." here's an example of a project they made, a motion-activated confetti canon ball. (laughter) but wait, this is actually my favorite project.
src_text: a few weeks ago we took littlebits to risd and gave them to some designers with no experience in engineering whatsoever — just cardboard, wood and paper — and told them "make something." here's an example of a project they made, a motion-activated confetti canon ball. (laughter) but wait, this is actually my favorite project.

tgt_text: it's a lobster made of playdough that's afraid of the dark.
src_text: it's a lobster made of playdough that's afraid of the dark.

tgt_text: to these non-engineers, littlebits became another material, electronics became just another material.
src_text: to these non-engineers, littlebits became another material, electronics became just another material.

tgt_text: and we want to make this material accessible to everyone.
src_text: and we want to make this material accessible to everyone.

tgt_text: so littlebits is open-source.

tgt_text: you can go on the website, download all the design files, make them yourself.
src_text: you can go on the website, download all the design files, make them yourself.

tgt_text: we want to encourage a world of creators, of inventors, of contributors, because this world that we live in, this interactive world, is ours.
src_text: we want to encourage a world of creators, of inventors, of contributors, because this world that we live in, this interactive world, is ours.

tgt_text: so go ahead and start inventing.
